reviewText:
Crusader Kings 2 is a complex grand strategy game.  The most complicated game I've ever played. Be prepared to spend hours and I mean hours confused as hell, looking at youtube, the wiki and forums.   Once it clicks though, it's awesome.  Not for everyone, but its kinda like playing through 'real life' Game of Thrones (there's a game of thrones mod too).

You control a land owning character starting on any date between 1066 and 1453 AD (The Old Gods DLC will push this starting date back to 867 if you wish).  You can start as a powerful emperor or a lowly count.  The map you play on is more or less Europe stretching into parts of Asia and Africa.  Your sole goal in the game is to keep your bloodline going (and I believe holding land).  Other than that, there isn't a win screen, there aren't defined goals, its open ended, you play until 1453AD and then the game ends (save exportable to Europa Universalis 4 to continue your game with the purchase of a DLC).  You get a 'score', but that is just a rough estimate on how prestigious and pious your bloodline was.  It's quite possible to have 400 years of super rewarding gameplay without getting a high score.  This is a trend you will see me developing on and is a big part of what makes CKII so awesome.

That's kinda hard to grasp, but it is less awkward than it sounds.  The goals sort of present themselves naturally.  You don't often sit there with no idea what to do (again, once you understand the game), you kind of always have something you're working towards.  For a first time player this is usually just become as powerful as possible, i.e. aquire land, become a king, then become an emperor and expand your empire.  If you're an advanced player you can set your own crazy goals, roleplay, or do other things to spice up the game.

The game runs in 'real time', with a day going by a few times a minute on normal speed.  You can fast forward and pause.  Most of the time you will indeed be going through various menus.  Arranging marriages, keeping tabs on powerful families, plotting assinations, acquiring territory through political shennigans, keeping your subjects happy, bringing in powerful characters to tutor the children of the realm and hold office, and much more.  You can micromanage to your hearts content, play a more hands off style, or switch between the two.

When combat breaks out, it is done by moving stacks of armys around the campaign map, meeting an opposing army will cause a battle.  These really just compose of watching numbers go down, and kills go up, so if you're looking for Total War style combat you arent going to get it here.  Don't be fooled though, many times I've been on the edge of my seat watching these numbers change.  The combat system is quiet nuanced as well. To be the most effective you have many things to consider. Terrain bonuses, attrition penalties, appointing competant commanders from your realm, and more add depth.

In all I highly recommend this game to anyone who has played something like Civ or Total War and fancy themself a strategy gamer, is looking for a challenege, and has a lot of patience.  This is kinda the next step you can take into something quite a bit more complicated.  That is the path I took into the game am loving it.

The game is still actively having expansions and patches developed for it as of the writing of this review 11/25/2013.

Full disclosure:  Your reviewer has not quite finished a playthrough yet but am close.  I have 120 hours playtime. I own the dlcs The Old Gods, Legacy of Rome, and the Europa Universalis 4 save converter.  I solely purchased EU4 because of how much I enjoyed my crusader kings 2 game and wanted to continue playing my empire, I haven't even played it yet.

Also: Don't buy for full price.  Even though it is worth it, getting the game and all the dlc all at full price is pretty expensive. The base game is often on sale or in bundles.

This is my first steam review so if you think this is helpful give the thumbs up and I'll do some more reviews.  Hope you enjoyed reading.

reviewText:
Dear Diary,

Day 1, I played CK2 as a Viking Lord in Norway. I was able to get FedualisAm and reformed Religion. 65 years old and on death door I was able to get Primogeniture passed as a tribe and formed kingdom of sweden and norway.

Day 2, Today the throne was passed to me by my father. I was able to take over Finland and Denmark to create an empire.
Found a new home in England and that will be the target of my son.

Day 3, My father was a viking berserker, He lead an army of 5000 men charging toward 3000 skirt troop but he was manage to get surranded and killed. I got on the throne just 14 years old and I will probably rule it a long time.

Day 4, I am still on the throne and now i am now 70 years old. A lot things happened and United Kingdom is now under viking Banner and I am still a bit short of forming the wendish empire. It's Already midnight here so a new day will start.

Day 5, It's pass mid night and i will play until i pass the throne to my son. as 70 I will need to slow down and manage my titles, county and Duchy well. Time to be a bit ruthless tyrant and once I die all bad behavior will be washed away.

PSSSSttt.. I am now 83 years old.. Why won't i die? All the vassal are extramly unhappy with me taking duchy, Banish overpowered lord. I had to bribe people regulary. Murder over powerful faction member. And forget about Fabricate Claims I need it to keep my subject happy.

MAARARAFDAAS... I am now 93 years old.. I accepted the fact that i won't die anytime soon And it's 5:30 in the morning already.

Meh.. This is a review? Not a Diary? Why are you Staring at my story.., Buy the game and start your own story.

Update:
A little update to the fun fact.. he finnaly died at 95. then the heir was 75 and died with the year then the heir was 59 and already mained and ill. He died in 3 month. Now i am playing as a 2 year old infant. Wow. I love this game.

reviewText:
Word of warning when buying this, it will will ruin all other strategy games!

I was a big Civilization fan and whilst it isn't really far to compare the two (they are wildly different in many ways) going back to something like Civ now seems like a huge leap back in terms of depth.

The politics, emergent story and shear possibility of genuine scheming in Crusader Kings 2 make other dilpomacy games almost a joke. Once you've conspired to kill a duke with the help of his wife and the hope of triggering a civil war to potentially swing in the favour of your first born heir as your final legacy, nothing will offer the same devious pleasure in other games.

By all means try the demo, but don't be scared off by the amount of information. Whilst great, the interface is certainly intimidating at first, but the tool tips are excellently written for just about every button. Just take your time and don't worry about losing to much at first, just mess around and it will soon come to you.

This is the type of game that makes you want to write down your stories just to share with other people. Like that time I murdered my own inbred daughter because she was in a plot with my uncle to kill me! Beat that!

reviewText:
I am sussex, one county in england at the 769 start.

I realize I picked a bad start, and need to get land fast. so I took over kent, the de jure duchy.

I am now the duke of Kent, but am stuck with mercia, wessex, and northumbria. so I decide to take those too.

I am now the king of England. Unfortunately, ireland and scotland seem to hate things that aren't celtic and think they can attack me at will. so I take them over.

I am content with staying on the empire of Britannia and never expanding as that brings trouble. except the vikings think they can constantly spam raids on me. so I take over all of scandinavia to stop the germanics.

now that I am no longer surrounded by long boats, I can finally rest...

and then the muslims invaded aquataine. realizing how screwed I am if the muslims manage to take france and germany, I proceed to commit genocide across the iberian peninsula to ensure christian safety. I can now finally stop conquering...

until I notice that africa is only made of muslims since the shia took over mali. so to make sure that I don't get steam rolled later, I take them over too...

I finally stop conquering for 50 years... until the mad emperor decides that he wants jerusalem, france, germany, italy and middle francia. so he conquers them all and eventually dies from a combination of stress, depression, and a wound.

good thing that his genius son managed to keep the empire from being broken apart from all the lords who just don't like the Haesting family. unfortantely, I lose jersualem from every single muslim joining the jihad. but thats okay, I pushed into egypt and took control of the byzantine empire.

The caliphate must have realized what I was planning, for 30 years after the fall of jerusalem he thought he could take anotolia. Neither he nor I expeceted the christianized mongolians helping me. I keep anatolia and eventually take back jerusalem.

on May 30th, 1350, I was crowned Roman Emperor and given the nickname 'the glorious'.

10/10, would restore rome as an anglo-saxon again.

EDIT: At 820 hours, I have finally beaten my first ironman game. This game lasts far too long if you start at the 769 date since the game lags bad at the end.

reviewText:
11/10 - Would become Earl Cadoc of Cornwall again.

CK2 – The Misfortune Simulator
The Life of Cadoc of Cornwall
William the Conqueror succeeds in his invasion of England, which is good as Harold was good for nothing.

In his wisdom, William decided to create the Duchy of Cornwall and NOT make me the Duke. I remain a lowly Earl.

Start plot to assassinate the current Duke of Cornwall, I want that position. Nobody likes me enough to join it. End of plot.

The only guy who actually liked me a lot and had great traits, my Chancellor, today died of depression. The only two suitable replacements look more like the living embodiment of the Seven Deadly Sins. I chose one of them with reluctance.

My wife is pregnant. Hopefully it'll be a boy!

My first daughter, whom is to be my heir, refuses to learn any of my traits. To this day, she remains Ambitious, and only Ambitious.

The child is born. It's a girl.

And to add the icing on the bitter Cake of Feudal Disappointment, my loving wife died giving birth to said child.

Got married again!

Wife insisted on becoming a Spymaster. Funny, both my wives have been Spymasters...

Treason! Rebellious scum have risen in Cornwall, and I am besieged. According to someone of little importance in my Council, this rebellion only had a 6.5% chance of actually happening. I should buy a ticket for the Great Monarch Lottery.

Duke Arsewipe of Cornwall has aided me in removing the rebellious scum that infested my lands. I still hate him.

Praise be to God! A plague of Typhus has swept Cornwall. Perhaps Duke Arsewipe shall be given a painful and miserable death.

Duke Arsewipe lives...yay.

My wife is pregnant, I hope it's a boy. I'm sure the saying goes “Second time lucky”.

Apparently the saying goes “Third time lucky”, and I am now the only man in a house of my wife and four daughters.

Instead of consoling me, today my Court Chaplain came to me to spread heresy. Naturally, I imprisoned him.

My Steward is dead, and there are no candidates to replace him. I now spend a portion of my day keeping the chair warm.

Today, I learned that Duke Arsewipe had a previous wife who tragically died of Camp Fever. I'm still unsure as to what the hell kind of name 'Hungifu' is for a woman. Those weird Anglo-Saxons.

My wife is once again pregnant. Since this is the 'third time', maybe I will be in luck.

My first daughter has married the son of the King of Denmark. We are now far more Prestigious, and Denmark are now my allies.

It's a boy! Cador is born!

My eldest daughter has given birth to a daughter.

My second eldest daughter has just married the son of the King of Navarra. We now have an alliance with Navarra. Duke Arsewipe better look over his shoulder from now on.

My niece has asked me to help her find a suitor to marry. Rather concerning is the fact that someone has put my newborn son on the list. I will choose her someone that isn't related.

I decided to hold a marvellous feast, with only the finest food. Unfortunately, I only have one guest. The feast went well.

Managed to convince my Bishop, whom was formerly my Court Chaplain, to become a Catholic once again. Upon doing so, I released him from prison.

I have started a new plot to kill Duke Arsewipe, and with a little (a lot) of coin, I have convinced two others to join me. At last, my enemy shall die!

For whatever reason only known to them, my two supporters backed out without telling me. To add insult to injury, Duke Arsewipe had the nerve to ask me to let a member of his family educate one of MY children!

Turned 50 today. Happy Birthday to me...yay.

Today, my WIFE discovered that my eldest DAUGHTER is planning to kill my only SON and heir. I think my family has finally hit rock bottom.

My wife is pregnant...

A boy has been born! This is becoming a big family, hopefully they won't murder each other.

Alas, sickness murdered my newborn son.

It's been twenty years since Duke Arsewipe became duke, and for some reason, he still insists on breathing more life into his wretched soul. I may be older, but I will outlive him!

My wife is pregnant...again. I really need to calm down in my old age.

It's a boy. The family seems to be evening out a bit now.

I have no idea how I do it, but I've managed to get my wife pregnant again. My Court Chaplain insists I stop these so-called “shenanigans”.

I am blessed with another son.

Duke Arsewipe has stepped over the line now. He has asked me to allow HIM to educate MY son and heir. May the Devil take him!

60 today. I insist upon outlasting Duke Arsewipe!

My eldest daughter's husband has died at the age of 31, and the circumstances are very suspicious.

My son and heir is now married to the princess of the Holy Roman Empire!

My half-brother, Dumnarth, died today. He will be greatly missed.

Insulted my wife by calling her gluttonous and a monster when it comes to table manners. I shall not be doing that again.

It is done. Duke Arsewipe finally had his last breath on August 1st, 1101 at the age of 69. I can now go to my grave a happy man.

At the age of 72, Earl Cadoc of Cornwall died after a period of illness on November 2nd, 1103. He succeeded in his goal of outlasting his mortal enemy.

reviewText:
Easily one of the best games I've had the fortune of playing. A grand stragey, which rather than being abstracted out to the extent of Civ or Europa Universalis, allows you to take on the role of a head of state (or, head of county or duchy) and do essentially what you like. Want to conquer Britain? Do it! Want to sit as a count for 400 years? Do it! Want to overthrow the Holy Roman Empire? Well... Good luck.

Although the core game only allows Christian rulers (thanks ahyangyi!)  to be played, Sword of Islam adds Islamic groups, The Republic adds republics, The Old Gods adds Pagans and Sons of Abraham adds the Jewish kingdom. Each provides a new style of gameplay, distinct from the others.

Grand strategy at its finest, though frustratingly hard at times.

reviewText:
Incest simulator ?This is the title that many jokingly have given this game on the internet.
However this far from what the game is, can you perform incest, yes, however the deepth and dynamics goes far beyond mere incestual relations.

Main purpose or goal?You are the head of a dynasty, at the beginning of the game, you can choose which dynasty, and who within that dynasty that you want to play as.
Do you want to take control of one of the powerful rulers of the mighty Karling dynasty?
Or do you want to repeat history by trying to bring a small count in Switzerland from an obscure family known as Habsburg to their glory, as Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire, and spread the Habsburg from there on.

With the customize ruler DLC you expand you game a thousandth-fold, you will have to power to not only choose who you want to play as, but you can create you whole new dynasty and ruler. Want a genius hunchback who rules over the Arabian Empire?
Do you want to try and backstab your way to the top of the Byzantine Empire with a powerful spy?
It is up to you!

There is one indicator on how well you have done, that is your Score which the game at the end compare with other great historical dynasties. You increase your score by having rulers with high prestige and piety, but also having other dynasty members in high positions, will generate prestige to your dynasty, giving newborn a higher starting position in life, when it comes to their prestige.

There are so many DLCs!Many seem to get overwhelmed by the amount of DLCs this game has, however many of those are cosmetic DLCs, adding other graphics or sounds to the game.

The main DLCs that expand gameplay are:

I will rank them, with the top being the most important expansion to get first, by my own opinion.

Ruler Designer - This will enable you to create your own ruler, only your imagination will limit the replayability of the game.
Legacy of Rome - This expansion not only gives more deepth to the Orthodox rulers of the Byzantine, and greek cultures, it also provides new game mechanics, such as military retinues. (Also allow the possibility for castrating and blinding prisoners playing as a ruler of the Byzantine culture group)
The Old Gods - This enable you to play the game from 867 CE, and also make Pagans and Zoroastrian rulers playable.
Sword of Islam - Makes muslims playable, as The Old Gods each unique religion has its own mechanics.
Sons of Abraham - Adds more deepth to the abrahamic faiths and also Judaism. Heresies for religions are also possible.
The Republic - Want to try out the merchant life of Venice? With this DLC that will be possible, take control of a patrician family, amass wealth and control the trade zones around the shores of the known world.
Charlemagne - Introduces a new starting time, at 769 CE, gives you the option to create custom Kingdoms and Empires.
Rajas of India - Allows for control of the Indian rulers.
Way of Life - Focus the life of your ruler towards certain areas of his life, want to became a great hunter to catch the fable white bear? Or became the greatest architech in the whole realm?
Customization Pack - Customize your ruler ingame, change the beard, hair style, even the dynasty name or shield.
Sunset Invasion - If you want to add an extra level of crazy to your game, only recommended for veteran players of CK2, what if the Aztec discovered Europe first? And decided to invade?
Save Game converter - If you own Europa Universalis IV and want to continue your saga from CK2, this DLC will enable you to export your CK2 game into EU IV.
All the other DLCs are cosmetical.

Mods!
Crusader Kings 2 has more mods, that will expand your game, one of the more popular mods is a total conversion into a Game of Thrones universe. Where you can encounter spoilers from the series, but it will also make you play out the stories in George R.R. Martin's universe in another direction, should Tyrion Lannister have the Iron Throne?

Learning curve?It has a steep learning curve, and the ingame tutorial only scratches the surface of possibilities. I would recommend picking up the game, and play with a friend online, or experiment as a count in Ireland.

But when you get a hang on it, it will grab you, and pull you deeper into a world of intrigue, murder, war, romance, and much more. In an forever going struggle for power over the realm, and the world.

reviewText:
If you care about the amount of gameplay you get for your money at all, this game probably rates higher than any other game. (Last I read, the average player had over 500 hours on this game.)

Crusader Kings II is a strategic game where you spend most of your time looking at a big map of Europe cut into little counties, but it is drastically different from a game like Medieval II: Total War.  Whereas in those games, every nation had rigid boundaries and an entire nation was a distinct, unified entity, Crusader Kings II focuses upon the feudal system of governance, and especially its hereditary system of succession.

You are not a nation, you are an extended family through the ages.  You may start as King of England, but lose the throne in a succession war, only to wind up inheriting the Kingdom of France, instead.  It is a game of political machinations more than warfare.

You can't just declare war whenever you want to, you need to, by hook or by crook, manage to get a claim to that land you want to invade.  Battles are relatively quick and hands-off (play that Total War if you want to manage the troops directly) but it's the space between wars that makes the game interesting.  To get that claim, you probably need to find some way to get the princess of that land in your bed (or your son's bed), and it's this medieval bloodline plotting that make up the meat of the game.

For that matter, you don't necessarily need to declare war to gain land - just marry into the family that succeeds a throne, and make sure that, one way or the other, your chosen heir also manages to be the chosen heir of a target kingdom, and the kingdoms will be unified upon the death of your current character and the current king of the target land.

Likewise, just because you gain land doesn't mean you can keep it.  You need to delegate land out, and succession laws can fragment your kingdom so much that you see hard-conquered lands slip out of your grasp by inheritence without your consent.

Worse, while whomever you give land will be quite grateful for the first 20 years of their rule or so, their children will have no gratitude for the gift of land your father gave them, and will likely be burning with ambitions you have to keep in check.  Every few decades, your character ages and dies, and succession wars and civil wars are the primary way the game keeps your over-arching ambitions in check.  Rather than letting a large empire mean that no external threat can challenge you, and no internal threats exist, the larger you become, the less vulnerable you are to external threats, but the more vulnerable you are to internal ones. You spend more and more time trying to find a way to bludgeon the rebellious nobles and religious minorities into line.

If you get tired of games of Total War, and don't bother completing them because, once you are the strongest power on the map, there's nothing to do but steamroll everything else that stands in your path, then CK2 is a great remedy to this.  (You can still make a world-spanning super-empire, but it's much more interesting to try to keep it when the owners of that land still fight you when you plant your flag there than to just have them mutely pay taxes to you and have assumed loyalty to your cause.)

It's a game that's just hard and realistic enough to make the things you do actually feel like you're thumbing your nose at history.  You can play an Irish earl, rise to High King of Ireland, and conquer England.  Or play as the West Africans, and conquer the Muslims and convert them to your pagan faith.  Being a norse viking that captures the pope and sacrifices him to Odin is always fun.  (And nabs the Holy Smoke! achievement.) And if you do it with an unbroken line of Viking empresses, all the better.

Mods are also a high point: Play the Elder Kings mod, based upon the Elder Scrolls, and conquer Cyrodiil and beyond as an immortal or vampire, using magicks to summong hordes of demons when under threat. There's an A Game of Thrones mod, as well, and mods to turn the game into something like a space 4X game.

DLC still comes out for the game, as well.  While more than a little annoying to be nickled and dimed, the trickle of new content keeps the game fresh and new achievements are meaningful challenges, requiring players to take up historic underdogs to rise to glory.  Getting a full board of achievements is extraordinarily difficult, but enjoyable for the challenge they provide.

reviewText:
* Started as a random count in Ireland in the 8th century.
* By 800 I had become King of Ireland.
* By 1000 I had established the Empire of Britain.
* By 1100 I had conquered all of France.
* By 1150 I had taken control of all of Italy and crowned myself Holy Roman Emperor.
* By 1160, I had launched a war on the Byzantine Empire, won, installed a Catholic on the Byzantine throne and by 1190 the Orthodox Church had been completely eradicated.
* By 1200 I had inherited the Byzantine Empire after marrying its Empress, and promptly established myself as the true Roman Emperor.
* By the game's end, the Irish Roman Empire controls the entirety of Western Europe and North Africa all the way up to Lithuania, Somalia and Persia, has entirely reversed the Arab conquests and seized control of Mecca and Medina (confining the Muslims to Eastern Arabia and Pakistan), and has even established several trade posts in India, effectively beginning the colonial period several hundred years early. Technology is incredibly advanced, heresies are spreading like wildfire and nobody really seems to care, so effectively the Enlightenment has begun several hundred years early as well. To top it all off, Iceland, the British Isles, most of France, most of North Africa and most of Hungary are now fully Irish.

This is just one of the things you can do in this game. Just one.
Do I recommend?
YES.

(Lag gets a bit bad in the late game, apparently because all the Greek characters are using up processing power trying to figure out who they can castrate out of all the characters in the game. Yes, you read that right - the game runs slow because the Greeks are trying to castrate the entire world. Other than that simultaneously annoying and hilarious problem, the game is great!)

reviewText:
Crusader Kings II is an exceptional game in that no other title will make you feel like a ruler as well as it. You're not just a country, like in other grand strategy games. You are a ruler with qualities, flaws, vices and virtues. You can be a Duke who is a brilliant diplomat with a hunchback, an ugly, stuttering dimwit count, or a mastermind plotter/lesbian queen. (I'm NOT making it up). And you can be all that within in a single playthrough, as you re-incarnate into your heir when you die. You have to be good at managing your realm, but you've got to be even better at managing your dynasty by arranging favourable marriages, assassinate pretenders... It's all very involving and requires a lot of micro-management (which you may or may not like).

It's not without flaws: the interface could see much improvement and the game starts to slow down when you become powerful. By slow down, I don't mean that your computer has a hard time coping, I mean that there are many more events that require your constant attention, making things move at a slower pace. To be honest, after several hundred hours, I think I'm a bit burned with the game. And that, even though there are entire DLCs I haven't really explored yet: I have only really played as a Catholic or Muslim ruler, but DLCs let you play as pagans, Orthodoxes, republics...

And then there are a couple of Mods that are probably worth exploring as well: Game of Thrones" and "Tamriel" (from the Elder scrolls series)

Still
date: with so much content and the unbeatable feeling of being an actual Middle-Ages ruler
recommended: it's hard to rate CKII anything lower than a 9 out of 10."

reviewText:
This is a good game.
A fantastic game, even. To my knowledge it's never really been done before (besides crusader kings I, obviously)
It's incredibly entertaining. You can do some absolutely hilarious things
Is it worth 40 USD? Of course
Does it cost 40 USD? Not quite

Scroll up
See that 'Downloadable content for this game' section? Click see all.
Scroll down
Yes, 194.49 218.46 USD. That's how much DLC is in this game. Remember all those youtube videos you watched? Remember how fun it looked? I can guarantee you most of the entertaining features you saw in that video are going to cost you at least another 5 USD each. Remember seeing that youtuber raiding england and pillaging all the churches as a viking warrior? 15 USD. Remember seeing them ruling mediterranean trade as the venetian republic? 10 USD. Remember how they conquered all of europe for the caliphate? 10 USD. Remember how they united india under one glorious empire? 15 USD. Remember how they designed their own character to conquer europe with? 5 USD.
Remember how not all of the different nationalities looked exactly the same? That's going to cost you another 2 USD per portrait set. Remember how not all of the units looked exactly the same? 2 USD per unit set. Remember all of that different music in the background? That's going to set you back as well

It's a great game
Would it be worth 40 USD? Yes
Is it worth 234.48 258.45 USD? No. Not at all. Which is why I couldn't possibly recommend it

Now, if there were a way to play the full game without spending hundreds of your hard-earned (insert currency here), then it would be a different story...

(EDIT) If you can catch it on a 75% sale like what's on until the 5th of october then that's a solid deal, just know that the 'collection' doesn't include all of the DLCs like you'd be forgiven for assuming

reviewText:
I will not talk about how Crusader King II compares to other strategy games on the market because it wouldn't be fair to them. You do not compare a Picasso with children drawings from school. Students have to do quick flashy drawings for good grades, and do them as often as they can, with accent on flashy rather than on detail. Crusader Kings II is a game that puts the accent more on detail, quality rather than quantity.

The game itelf may feel a bit hard to understand at first, but if you give it a moment of your time, it will surprise you. But buyer be warn, if you just wanna play a game where you plug in, then all you do is fancy easy war TW style, or EUIV, then better avoid CK2. Crusader Kings II requires the player to think, quite a bit actually, and consider choices and plan ahead, sometimes for a few decades. It is a real strategy game, and as such it is a gem, since I do not think there is another game on the market that challenges you truly at this level and in such a complex way.

Why is it challenging? Well for one, you need to plan your dynasty, you need to plan your marriages to seek advantages and gains, secure the blood line, be wary of who will you end up playing next, and after that, manage your vassals, manage alliances which can only be made through marriage, manage your holdings so you can have more income and troops, manage your realm to pick laws which will either upset or make your vassals happy, or play nice to your liege if you are not independent, watch over your armies when you raise them, pick terrain carefully as it matters quite a bit, be carefull who you put in charge of your armies, watch over you flanks, be carefull what troops you use when, since the holding they come from gives them bonuses, plan your technological advancements, mind religion, convert, play the cardinal game, expand, go on crusades, plot to murder your enemies, to revoke titles, fabricate claims, and so much more.

You think that list is big? Its small, even more so, get a mod from the Paradox Forums, and you can get 2-3 times more features, some mods even take you to other worlds, use maps from settings you know and love and add a ton of events and new features. The ammount of depth this game and its modding community offer is mind boggling. Crusader Kings 2 is the Skyrim of Strategy Games. Its got depth, its got versatility, its got deep modability, its a gem.

And trust me, nothing compares to the feel you get, when after starting as a Count, you end up an Emperor for the first time...

reviewText:
This is by far the most accessible of the Grand Strategy Games that Paradox has made. A wonderfully convoluted game, where you define your goals and the means to achieve them. Be warned, you learn this game by playing it, gradually blooming into one of the most magnificent machiavellian meanies (darn you, profanity filter) the world has ever seen. Rewrite history as you see fit, Scheme and plot, command armies and then laugh at your demise at the hands of your subjects, your enemies, your supposed friends, your children and the wonderfully cruel winds of change and chance.

But be warned, this game does not provide you with a goal aside from survival of your dynasty. Do you wish to unite Ireland and then subjugate the heathens that currently hold Jerusalem? How about bringing forth the downfall of the Holy Roman Empire as just a lowly Count of France? Or maybe you really just want to make that one guy pay who plotted the death of your insane, crippled and infirm Court Jester? Do what you want and suffer the consequences.

All in all, this game is ripe with dark humour and seems to be easy at first. But it deceives you, sucking you in and suddenly gripping you by the balls, as you die from consumption, your son gets killed in a crusade and your remaining heir turns out to be gay, possessed and a complete lackwit, all while your allies drag you into wars and your vassals rise up in arms against you.

So, laugh at the cruel twists of fate, or grow mad from the revelation. Or maybe just enjoy a quiet, uneventful life as a lowly vassal to better lords.

reviewText:
I didn't know what to write about in my review, so here's a recipe for pancakes instead:

1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 1/2 teaspoons baking powder
1 teaspoon salt
1 tablespoon white sugar
1 1/4 cups milk
1 egg
3 tablespoons butter, melted

1. In a large bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, salt and sugar. Make a well in the center and pour in the milk, egg and melted butter; mix until smooth.

2. Heat a lightly oiled griddle or frying pan over medium high heat. Pour or scoop the batter onto the griddle, using approximately 1/4 cup for each pancake. Brown on both sides and serve hot.

reviewText: I'm going to tell you a brief history of the magnificent and prestigious Pasta family; one of the most prevalent Venetian trades families that reigned Venice on and off for some 600 years.\n\nThroughout their years and with a very sordid and complicated family tree the Pasta family (stemming from their patriarch, Serene Doge Spaghetti I The Fat") came to amass a previously unthought-of level of wealth. Legend has it that in the late 11th century Venetian spending ground to a complete halt as the city-state had quite literally too much money and not enough places to invest in. A ruthless and cunning family
date: the Pasta family spared no expense in making sure their trade ports were renowned the world over. If money was being spent in the Mediterranean
recommended: the Pasta family got a cut; to do business and avoid them was difficult. To avoid Venice altogether was impossible.\n\nWhile avoiding open conflict as much as they could
hoursPlayed: the Venetians did get in a few trade squabbles with the Amalfi
voteText: only to render the Greek patricians an afterthought when it came to doing business in the Mediterranean. Using a mix of intrigue and some well-placed military show-of-force
helpfulPercent: the Pasta patricians were able to get a monetary lock on almost the entire Mediterranean Sea
votesHelpful: and were even looking to find a weak county along the Red Sea to capture so as to expand their trade empire into India. Venice made many political and cultural strides in southern Europe
votesTotal: notably by turning its back on Roman Catholicism in 1207 to adopt the Cathar heresy. This did very little to dissuade people from trading with them
votesFunny: however
commentsCount: as Rome itself was home to a particularly busy Pasta trade port for several hundred years at that point.\n\nIt wasn't until Serene Doge Cavatappi III in 1349 did cracks begin to form in the illustrious Pasta mansion
column16: so to speak. Through a series of marriages to various Saxon and Bavarian princes the Pasta family came in posession of a few counties in mainland Europe; far away from warm
column17: balmy climate of Venice. Sitting on a veritable mountain of gold at this point
column18: the Venetian powers that be tended to ignore their lands to the north
column19: and left it in the capable hands of their respective rulers. After Penne IV
column20: son of Cavatappi III lost the election to become the next Serene Doge (an event that did happen a few times during the 600 year Pasta tenure
column21: but few and far in between)
column22: he decided to turn his back on Venice altogether and tore his family's ties from the Republic. Adopting a few of his rightful counties in Bavaria and suffering a hard but brief blow from the bizarre Sunset Invasion
column23: Penne and his kin lived in a financial nightmare. While by no means broke
column24: the family now had a mere fraction of the wealth they amassed during their mainstay in Venice.\n\nThe reason not much has been written about the Pasta family is because after this exodus the dynasty pretty much lost all of its prestige and money. Left with a few counties in Saxony (which were quickly overthrown by their bigger and more powerful Frankish neighbors) and no historical records left over save for a few manuscripts found in the wine cellar of the old Pasta mansion (discovered only recently)
column25: the Pasta family became a cold
column26: stale remnant of what it once was. The only surviving history of the family for a while was of its brief stay in mainland Europe
column27:
which was far from glorious.

...

I did all of this by clicking things on a map and looking at spreadsheets.

10/10 would create a grand trade empire only to fade into obscurity and have a terrible score at the end of the game again."

reviewText: Endless replayability. CKII may take a while to get into, but once you learn about most, if not all game features, you'll find countless things you can do or try to achieve. Story unfolds itself, because while there is no narrative or script, your actions and actions of others really change the world and characters around your dynasty. Vast personal traits and characteristics that every single one character in game can have make up the story, as their actions are mostly defined by the personalities they have.

reviewText:
Quite simply one of the greatest strategy games ever made.

From the outset - Crusader Kings is not for everyone.

It will be best enjoyed by people who are interested in deep systems and the interplay between them. Those seeking a way to crack the optimal" way to play
date: and those seeking to "win" will be disappointed
recommended:
whereas those seeking emergent systems and effects will enjoy hundreds of hours of discovery.

It is therein that lies CK2's greatest strength - creating a narrative through emergent systems.

Crusader Kings II relies largely on the player setting their own goals and then working towards them. Be they immediate goals
voteText: or long term dreams
helpfulPercent: a large part of CK2's appeal lies in pondering how best to "exploit the code" to reach your ends. In fact
votesHelpful: the best way to play CK2 is not to play to win
votesTotal: but to let the game "happen"; to let your dynasty's fortune ebb and flow with the passage of time
votesFunny:
creating a narrative of a family streching across the centuries.


Crusader Kings 2 is a game that you can sink literally hundreds of hours into and still find out new and exciting things to do. CK2 isn't a perfect game; the learning curve can be steep

reviewText:
Let me tell you a little story.

I was a mere count in Italy, an unimportant man, living my little life, raising my son, loving my wife. But I was pretty popular among other counts and dukes and so it happened that I was elected a king of Italy. Being young and ambitious I started to build my kingdom and earn the fame and glory I knew I was destined for. My reign was glorious, no revolts, no problems, only growth and prosperity and so holding a great tournament seemed like a great idea. But I was a diplomat, not a warrior and so it happened that I got maimed. Two years later I died of a combination of my wound and common flu. My 15 years old son became the king, but the vassals didn´t like him and soon enough they asked him to hand over the crown. He wasn´t gonna give it up so easily and so the war over the kingdom of Italy began. However my son underestimated the strength of his opposition and was forced to surrender. The new king imprisoned him and refused to ransom him, because he still had a claim on the kingdom. Three years later my son died and because he had no heirs, the game was over.

This little story, my friends, is the reason why I f*cking love this game.

reviewText: Scene: The Duke of Edessa, finally recovering from a recent Muslim invasion and the wounds suffered from it, invaded by the neigboring Byzantine Empire. His armies are crushed and his son is captured and castrated. He loses the war and is left as a one provice minor. He catches the plague and goes insane. He vows his revenge. 100 years later another Duke of Edessa and Antioch, now a vassal of Byzantium, begins revenge for the misfortunes of his ancestor. First he weasles his way into the current Emperor's inner circle and gains his trust. He then seduces all of his daughters and has a child with one of them. He then kills all of the sons of the Emperor, while luckily not being caught. He then recognizes the illegitimate child as his own. He then kills his wife and marries the byzantine emperor's daughter, who promptly dies of syphilis. He then  marries the daughter of the HRE thus forming an alliance with them. He then bides his time until the Empire is at its weakest point. The wait was not long, since 5 years later the Caliph of the Sunni faith called a Jihad for Anatolia. The emperor won the Jihad, but at the expense of most of his armies. The Duke, after waiting patiently for so long struck at the rival family. He raised all of the men of the land and used every last coin enlisting the help of mercenary bands. They marched towards Constantinople to meet the Imperial forces. After winning the battle the duke laid siege to the city. Just as the war was about to be won, syphilis struck again not only killing the duke, but his sons as well, leaving the fate of the dynasty and the war in the hands of a 62 year old, possessed, insane and childless relative. All hope was beginning to fail as the war took a turn for the worst. Then in final attempt at survival he sent the last of his armies to face the larger byzantine force. Then in a stroke of luck during the battle, his troops we able to capture the emperor and his last surviving son. He then in a bout of madness castrated all of his prisoners including the emperor and his son. The war ended and the emperors daughter took the throne, the 62 year old then attempted to seduce woman multiple times until finally it suceeded after his 65th birthday. A sickly, clubfooted, imbicile child was born, who the duke legitimized. He then killed the childs mother and himself leaving the young 1 year old as emperor. The duke's revenge finally seemed complete, until the one year old died from syphilis. (I have no idea how he got syphilis)\n\n10/10 would syphilis again

Angry Rant

I'm tired of all these DLCs and their inflated prices. The content added often brings new depth to the game, but frequently has features that we shouldn't have to pay for. I'm looking at you Ruler designer! Also you dirty portrait, unit and music packs should be ashamed of yourselves for existing! If you look at other game companies, they often give comparable content for free as an update. At the very base of it, I'm sick of all this piece meal DLC. reviewText:
An Indian family fleeing from oppression in their home province found asylum in my Kingdom of Norway. Why not, I thought. The father of the family was a decent warrior, so I allowed him to command troops in battle. He distinguished himself in many wars over the years and was awarded one of the recently conquered counties in Northern Germany. He continued to serve me loyally and has even converted to Norse religion. For his service I gave him a duchy to rule. Generation after generation his descendants continued to marry local nobles.

Now, nearly two centuries later, Germany is ruled by white dudes in turbans who think they're Indian, worship Norse gods and train War Elephants. Breaking history has never been so much fun!

I started playing CK2 during a free weekend. It looked like something I might like, so I gave it a try. I bought the game the next day along with several DLCs and never stopped playing. CK2 has now climbed to number 1 of my most played Steam games, in spite of being in my library for less than a year. I don't recall another game addiction" that lasted this long for me. And there is the fact that nearly 400 hours into the game I've only played as one of the many game religions
date: one of the numerous cultures (disregarding the training scenario). Playing as a different religion
voteText: starting rank changes the way you play the game. You could even start your second play through in the exact same character as last time and the way things will go will be entirely different.\n\nThis game is more complex than any other strategy I've played before. It takes a while to take it all in. Luckily there are in-game hints to what every screen means and what every button does (you can switch these off later
helpfulPercent: but I found myself checking every now and then). There is also a tutorial campaign that will teach you how to play.\n\nWhat adds to the fun greatly is the fact that you play as a specific character. Their traits and abilities make them more appropriate for certain roles within the Kingdom than others. The current King might make a better priest than military commander
votesHelpful: but you don't say that out loud in front of your liege (or their spymaster). Once your character dies
votesTotal: you play as the heir to their titles
votesFunny: this being usually one of their children
commentsCount:
depending on the hereditary laws of your realm.

Feel like expanding your Empire? You don't necessarily need to wage war to achieve that. Why don't you marry your eldest son to that second daughter of the neighboring empire and then make sure the first-born daughter (already married) has a little accident before she has children?
However as I am not the patient type I prefer marching my armies into enemy territory and be done with it. What I love about the battles is that the smallest thing can change the outcome of the battle (much like in history). The commander of your strongest flank was killed shortly after the skirmish began and his confused troops now run around the battlefield like headless chickens? Well
column16: s**t happens.\n\nThere is always a chance
column17: however small
column18: that things will go wrong. It's up to you to play the odds (don't put your only heir in battle
column19: especially while he's sick) and have a backup plan in case things don't go your way or you might end up losing your realm
column20: or the entire game. Once I lost a major battle and most of my personal army. One of my vassals decided now was the good time to revolt
column21: my stronger neighbor saw it as an opportunity to invade and on top of that a peasant uprising started in one of my counties. Bottom line - I lost it all and had to make tribal huts in Norway my capital
column22: which was a bummer after living in a mighty castle in Western France for two generations.\n\nThe good news is you can appoint commanders as you see fit
column23: provided your authority within the realm is strong enough to do so. Each of the several types of troops (and culture specific special units) has a different attack and defend stats and these evolve as you research technologies and construct special buildings. Your commanders can employ various tactics during battle
column24: some of which depend on their personal traits and/or martial capability.\n\nThere are many situations you will find yourself in - often thanks to random events
column25: most of which require very specific conditions to be met first. Many events are bound to a specific time and realms that existed at that point. I will not spoil these for you because I found it to be a lot of fun to face some of them followed by a palm on the forehead and an exclamation: “Of course
column26:
I (sort of) remember this from history lessons!”

I’ve always been interested in history and considered my knowledge of geography very decent and yet I’ve learned a lot of new facts by playing CK2. My natural curiosity took over and I've since researched many medieval realms and rulers online.

If you’re feeling competitive then know that achievements are only awarded if you play on Ironman mode. So please make sure that if you come across a player with some of the most difficult of achievements you salute and/or bow as appropriate.

At some point you might find yourself lying on your death-bed. Your son and heir might be an imbecile
column27: your younger brother has possibly convinced half of your court he'd make a better King than you and yet you’ll enjoy every minute of it. This game has my full recommendation.\n\nIf this looks like something you might like then give it a try. But be warned - You might be buying the new number 1 in your library and may thus face the "Should I do something meaningful with my day or should I finally become the King of England?" decision. And we both know it can only go one way from there."

Edit: I'm about to pass over six hundred hours of playtime on this game and it's all pretty much legitimate. No other game has held my attention for as long as Crusader Kings 2 has. Years have passed and I still come back to this game simply because there is still so much more to do and Paradox Interactive has done a tremendous job in supporting the game with content post-release. Simply put, Crusader Kings 2 is my favorite game of all time, hands down.


I've spent over three hundred hours on this game and I don't regret a single minute. Well, not exactly. I regret a lot of things done during my playthrough of this game but it happens after playing a dynasty for four hundred years! reviewText:
This used to be my favorite game ever. I have hundreds of hours logged into this game. I even loved crusader kings 1.

But Paradox has decided to let some no talent idiots take control of the Crusader Kings 2 project. Essentially they have repalced the main development team and the vision of the game has drastically changed. I have almost all the DLC's for this game and have spent quite a bit of money on it and NOW they start ruining it? Instead of giving us new things to conquer or new characters to interact with or new cool things to do they have decided just to make the old things harder and more annoying.

Between conclave and the proposed black death dlc the developers are severely limiting game play by injecting annoying, illogical and unrealistic events into the game. People already plotted to rebel and acquire power for themselves but conclave made it easier for them. There were already illnesses that caused quite a bit of devastation in the game so the new DLC is proposed to maximize that already annoying situation. What fun is that going to be?? Well let me tell you it will be about as fun as micromanaging all your vassals is in Conclave. Basically none. The UI and real time mode of game play severely limit micromanagement oppurtunities.

I am very unhappy with the direction crusader kings 2 is going with the dlc's and I will no longer be purchasing them. But even that doesn't stop the new jerk developers because they patch in idiotic things like broken retreat into the game whether you like it or not. I have quite a bit of money wrapped up in this game and the jerks have made it unplayable. The developers are so arrogant and foolish they don't even make their stupid new rules optional.

This is what happens when you don't allow negative feedback on your forums and fill it with bootlicking yes men. They pretty much ban anybody who makes the slightest criticisms of their games on their forums. Don't believe me go and see. Screw you paradox. No more money for you.

reviewText:
This was my experience:
Play a few games but I don't really understand the game. Finally after an hour and a half of going throught the tutorials a second time I figure it out. Start up an empire in Iceland. I don't bother anyone. I marry a Danish girl and help out my father-in-law with a rebelion and a small war but I don't really cause any trubble. The king of Norge (Norway) keeps wanting to start wars though. One day I get a letter, he wants peace as long as I fly his flage. Seeing as my wife was sick and had died a month before and her father was now losing a war I did not have the gold to help him win I had no other choice but to submit and accepted Norge rule. Immediatly the King of Norge invites me to his grand feast. He treats me well and offers me protection and safety. Alpha as ♥♥♥♥ King of Norge fights the Scots who have been bothering me for years. I ask if my son can marry his beautiful daughter who will one day be the Queen of Norge, and without question or hesitation he sends his daughter to Iceland and congradulates me on entering the family. WIth this my son is happy and I can concentrait on my kingdom. Over the next few years I build up a great army and nearly 1000 gold in wealth. However, I am an old man. I fear the fate of my father, I fear that soon I will die. The King of Norge is not a young man either anymore. One day I get another letter. The King of Norge is plaining to invade Scotland. Seeing as my other son married Godwinson (The King of England)'s daughter I was prepared to invade Scotland and claim all of  England and thus most of northern Europe for the King of Norge. I constructed a fleet of ships, hired thousands of men from the country side and some extra mecenaries just in case, and set sail. This time I was prepared for battle, I knew what would come. It was minutes laters as I prepaired my assault that I watched a Scotish fleet came from the deep ocean and landed on my shores and slaughter my people. Half of Scotland fought me in Scotland while the other half banded together and invaded my homeland of Iceland.

And that folks is the story of how Crusader Kings II gives you a cookie, lets you eat it and enjoy it before slaping you across the face and wash your mouth out with soap and hot sause. And I'll be god damned if it wasn't the most fun I've ever had. I laughed and I cried. I was filled with joy and then crushed with defeat. I was a king...I was THE KING...and then I was nothing...

11/10 would loose everything again

reviewText: Crusader Kings II on first look seems like just another game styled after so many other well-known games that use an overhead map and a time period. That’s where things steer into a different direction. This game may well be the best game created by the game smiths at Paradox Development Studio. It’s a huge strategy game with layers. I would suggest running the tutorial in the game. In fact I would also suggest keeping the hints option on, it is full of valuable playing information.Taking place over a 400 year time span the players take on the persona of a character running the realms and struggling to make it in these troublesome times.Throughout the game life, the character deals with the world and other characters of the court, they have stats and traits; they marry, and have children in hopes of conceiving an heir to the throne. That is the main point too, having a legitimate heir to the kingdom. As that first main character grows older and or dies before their time, as long as there is an heir the game goes on to 1452. Hierarchy and the bloodline are of some importance in this game as it was in yee olden days.The game plays in different ways depending on how the player chooses to start. Hierarchy plays a role here. So if the player starts out as a lower rank of the upper class, say a Count, well you have some leveling to do. There is so much information to be had during game play it can be over whelming at times; thankfully Paradox Development Studio has integrated so many buttons and drop downs to assist the player in keeping track of events and information. Plus the game can be paused to take a break or assess the situation. The interface and game play seems polished enough, though the animations took some getting used to.As gaming goes in the grand strategy style, there is some replay ability here, with so much going on, try different playing styles, be aggressive, or less so. See how things turn out, be a tyrant if you like.The graphics of the lands and seas are beautiful to behold, with clouds shadow and weather passing over the lands as you look down from your almost celestial view from above. Sound is pleasing as well, with music and sound bites setting the mood for events appropriately. This is truly one of the better games to come out from Paradox Development Studio, now like most strategy games, things do not progress always at a fast pace. So some patience in gaming is involved here. Crusader Kings II is exactly the sort of game I was hoping it would be. As deep and complex as its predecessor, but more accessible.

reviewText:
-Plays multiplayer as king of Denmark with a buddy as king of Sweden. We unite Scandinavia and reform the faith. I basically become the Pagan Pope.

-The King of both France and Germany (Charlemagne's empire before the creation of Holy Roman Empire) dies... last and only heir is a guy exiled in muslim Spain who converted to Allah.

-King of France and germany is now muslim zealot, refuses to convert to christianity, forces most aristocrats to convert to Islam and uses them to convert the people too.

-Allies himself with Muslim Spain and proclaims Jihad after Jihad on us because the Pagan holy sites we captured used to be Frankish lands. Muslims form the most powerful alliance in Europa. We hold our ground, losing and taking back Saxon lands. We pillage neighbouring lands to invest into the army when the onslaught begins anew.

-Catholic brits and italians send crusade after crusade to try and retake Catholic lands to no avail. They slow the Andalus down but they keep coming to die in the frozen wastes... It has been 5 Jihads now. Around 20.000/30.000 soldiers thrown at us...EACH TIME.

-We manage incredible victories due to clever strategy. We counter-attack with our own holy wars because they cannot declare war on us at their leisure during truce. I take the lands of Flanders. My friend takes Germany, I crown him Emperor of the Germanic people, bulwark of the faith.

-Most of France is converted now. The holy wars still rage on, though the muslim threat is being contained by a clever use of Pagan and Christian Holy wars during muslim internal struggles in order to even the odds.

-The last king of Italy dies and the Byzantine Emperor inherits the title. A new challenger joins the fray. Stronger than ever. Catholic Aquitaine revolts and with our indirect help, becomes independent.

-Yet it does not end... I can already hear the warcry of the faithful heathens coming to spill our blood. Allahu Ackbar... Allahu Ackbar...Ragnarok, the end times, are coming and it's symbol is a golden crescent.

10/10 Would create nightmarish dystopian far-right propaganda by accident again.

reviewText:
Crusader Kings II
Name  - Crusader Kings II

Genre - Grand Strategy

Personal Opinion - The best strategy game there ever was!

This is a pretty big game and this is my first review, so I won't delve into it too deep!
Also time played is not true, I have played this game quite a lot offline, unfortunately it does not show offline play hours.

Review
Crusader Kings II, a game where you can be a King, a Duke, a Count, or even an Emperor, with each level of nobility bringing a new level of difficulty, whereas if you start as a Count, you may start with only one province and depending on where you start you might end up being a vassal to someone else or even have some of your own!

Given that you are a vassal, you  may   will  have to compete with other vassals, who will either be lower or higher than you, in some cases you might join a faction with other vassals to try and force the current leader of the country to do things, such as lowering taxes and gaining independence, if you gain enough support you can get things in motion by issuing an ultimatum to the Emperor/King/Duke asking for these things, and if they refuse, you will be able to start a war to get it happening.

Then there's marriage, you can just about marry every single person in your kingdom, given that they aren't the same sex as you and they are 16 or over, however you can arrange a marriage for people under 16 (Betrothal).

Of course it doesn't just end there, after marriage you can have little clones of yourself (Kids), and build your dynasty, then marry em' off and possibly inherit more land!

Also, there are some awesome events that are random and pretty fun. Such as being a lunatic and appointing your horse as your chancellor, or giving birth to the anti-christ. Also, being an absolute tyrant and just murdering your way to the top.

Why not discover the What if" part of history

reviewText:
Do I recommend this game?
Yes, truly I do. Its an awesome game. It develops every single aspect of a strategy game set in the past that are left out of other games. You can have families, friends, allies, non-aggression pacts. You can imprison, execute and banish annoying vassals, you can marry yourself with the daughter of the King of England, and  through the descendants of that union get a claim on his lands. The game is varied, as you an set your game in various time periods across history with hundreds of different factions. You can be a Mongolian Khan or a Holy Roman Emperor just as much as you can be a count in Iceland with no wealth, armies or power. In most strategy games, who YOU in an empire is mostly irrelevant. In the CIV series you're simply a great leader of your nation that rules it forever. Or in the Total war series, you can have a defined character bu everything about him is mostly out of your control or irrelevant. in CK2, all the focus is on your family, as it should be. Your daughters can be married to secure alliances or become great rulers in their own right. Your sons can lead your armies, and can be giving titles you win through war. Some of your sons will love you, others will only try to seize power for themselves. Every single character as a personality, related to their trait that ACTUALLY MATTERS. Be a jerk, become a tyrant and people will hate you, resent you and might even try to murder you This world feels organic and you truly feel a part of it. For all of those reasons, I recommend this game

However

It cant be denied that this game unfortunately has TONS of issues that affect game play. The kind of which will make you want to scream at your screen at how stupid what just happened was. Complete nobodies who actually like you will have you murdered for no reason or  will get themselves 20000 men armies out of nowhere to attack you even tough they don't have a penny on them or apparent claims on your lands.

The AI can be incredibly stupid! They cant ever hold on to a king title without being crushed by continuous groups of rebellious vassals. After a century, ever single important christian kingdom will have an elective system of law. Why? Because its what theirs vassals want and the AI cant handle rebellions. You want to battle certain foreign dynasties across history? Too bad, the AI is also incompetent at keeping themselves alive for any long periods. Most great houses in say, 1066 will have disappeared in a bout a century  which COULD be considered historically accurate but at the same time it makes you feel like you're playing this game alone with no actual competition. The AI for the pope can be brain dead. Calling crusades against Kingdoms in India, forcing crusaders to cross the Persian desert to reach their target!

The DLC in this game is horrendous. Its DLC whoring that's EA worthy. You have to pay for portraits and songs in the game!!! PURE AESTHETICS STUFF THAT DOESNT CHANGE GAME PLAY. Are you sick of hearing the same 2 god damn songs in repeat? Pay money.
The worst about those DLC is what they offer. Without paying extra, you cant play pagans, you cant play Indians, you cant play muslims and you cant play republics. Thats right, more than half of the starting areas are impossible for the player to play unless they pay extra. Others are simply broken and as such are complete rip offs AND THANK GOD I never bought some of them!! They allow you for 5.49 $ to customize your ruler on regular mode BUT not on Ironman mode. But, thats something you could ALREADY DO THROUGH THE CONSOLE. Its vastly useless! The Way of life DLC makes every single male in your kingdom horny dogs that go after your wife, your heirs wife etc... which means, in a game about dynasties ruling across history, your son might just be the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ son of some random count who, thanks to the seduction focus, repeatedly slept with your wife 35 times right under your nose. The ONLY way to make sure your wives don't end up sleeping with every single man in the Kingdom is to pick a chaste one (trait that I rarely see and that they often end up losing) or a lesbian. Apparently, according to paradox, all women were ♥♥♥♥♥s in these times! Seeing how they refuse to truly fix this, thats the only conclusion I can arrive to. They tried to with a new reject seduction attempts" system but since theres always a few master seducers running around it doesn't stop anyone.
The conclave DLC makes the game way harder and sooo much less fun. The Republic DLC forces you to use seniority succession and nothing else! Always playing 75 years old? isnt that fun???
The Sword of Islam dlc should've been in the base game
date: same for the old gods. There's no excuses to leave so many factions unplayable even at an 1066 start.\n\nTheres also new updates. Lots of complaints about the new update regarding coalitions that can make pagans
recommended: muslims and christians band together against you because you took a duchy through a religious war. They NEVER make coalitions USEFUL agaisnt the AI

reviewText: It's not that I don't like this game, but the DLC is completely ridiculous. Expansions are alright, but there is no reason that they have to release other DLC with them. They have already released face packs, music packs, dynasty shield packs, and probably something else that I'm forgetting, and in their latest expansion, Charlemagne, Paradox proved that they are experts at squeezing every last dollar out of their customers. Just when I thought they had run out of face and music packs to sell, they added clothing packs. There is absolutely no reason that these cosmetic changes can't come bundled for free or at a reduced price with the expansions. In total, Crusader Kings II DLC now costs over one hundred and seventy-five dollars. While there is nothing wrong with the game by itself, the DLC model that Paradox uses is horrible, and is only defended by a group of people that have a cult-like devotion to the company.

reviewText:
So I was playing through this marvolous game and this happened.

The Cadaver Synod: You have received strange news from Rome. The former Pope, Pope Victor II, did by his actions and lifestyle so defile the Holy See that the current authorities in Rome decided to put his corpse on trial! The corpse of Pope Victor II was removed from its tomb and brought to the papal court for judgement. It was propped up on a throne, and a deacon was chosen to speak for it as its legal representative.
Perhaps unsurprisingly, the accused was found guilty on all accounts and subjected to a punishment most dire. The corpse was stripped of its papal vestments, three fingers on the right hand (those used to give blessings) were cut off, and then it was interred in a graveyard normally reserved for foreigners and low status. The punishment still not being deemed severe enough, the corpse was then exhumed again, tied to weights and cast into the river Tiber.

Your only choice of responce to this news: I am sure the judges have acted wisely.

Bruuuh.. the church go hard.. Mafia < The Christian Church. 11/10 would convert to Christianity again.

reviewText:
After a dozen games that ended misrably for my character and his dynasty within only a few years after starting the game, I have finally started a game that lasted for more then twenty minutes.

I started out as Leon, and all was well. Nothing happened, all my vassals were cool with me. Then I realized my kin in Aragon started to invade the moslems below us. Not wanting to be overpowered by Aragon a century later, I proceeded to take a small coastal province. I then promptly forgot what I was doing and spammed summer fairs and feasts for a decade or two.

When my first character died(Alfonso), he had quite the sum of prestige(around 500 or so). And, with the game engine doin' its thing, Alfonso's succesor(his son Alfonso) got around 200 prestige. Following his dear father's footsteps, Alfonso Jr. spammed the ever-loving crap out of feasts and festivals. But, not more then five years into his reign the pope rang him and asked him to join in a crusade against the moslems. Coincedentially, the targets for Christiandom's righteous wrath happened to be the nation directly below me.

So, of course, Deus Vult and all that. I invaded two small provinces in the first part of the crusade. After conquering these two places, I sat on my bum and waited the crusade out, jealously guarding my newly acquired lands.

Then, suddenly, as though the Heavenly Father himself thanked me for my participation in the crusade, I acquired half of Spain.

Not really sure how.

But, Now my prestige started to sky rocket. First, it was 300. Then it was 400. Then, 500. 600. 700. And on, and on and on it went until I had nearly 900 prestige by the time I was thirteen. Que another decade or so of me stealing tiny chunks of realms from the muslims that remained in Spain. Not only was I the terror of the muslims, I had backed the nation of Aragon into a corner, with only two land-locked provinces and a handful of coastal lands.

I then married the Queen of France.

And, by the time I reached my mid twenties, I was the stuff of legend. Having already held my Grand Tournament and accumulated nearly 2000 prestige, I was on top of the world. Loving wife how owns the entirety of France, promising sons, total alegience of all my vassals.

Then I became a homosexual.

Nothing wrong with that, not even my vassals batted an eye at it.

But they started to get worried when I went insane. Barking at people, wearing shoes as hats, the usual crazyness.

I also happened to be fighting a war with Britain in defense of France at the time, all while manipulating the law to make my son's kingship more secure.

Then I ♥♥♥♥ed up. I failed to see that choosing Senoirity as my inheritance guideline, I completely removed all of my children from the line of inheritence. Instead, It was my cousin.

But, you know what they say, practice makes perfect.



TL;DR
Became one of the most legendary kings by the age of thirteen, married the queen of France, went insane screwed over my family. This game is a must buy.

reviewText:
Ultimately, after 200 hours on a game (I'm not really a gamer so 200 hours is _insane_ for me to spend on a game) like this, you'd think I could recommend Crusader Kings II. Sadly, I am just not able to anymore. My view of CKII is pretty mixed, so I'll try to give the good with the bad. I'll start with the good first, since I plan to expand more on the bad.

THE GOOD
-The map is gorgeous and easily the best looking of all of Paradox's games.
-Music, even without the music pack DLCs, is pretty great and I've never really gotten tired of it.
-The history is, at least on the surface, simulated pretty well and I enjoy having some of the weirder and obscure characters in history able to be played like the last Karling, a random Christian ruler in Seljuk Anatolia, and so on. It's nice that they'll include stuff like that even if you can only access it by skipping to a very specific year.
-The early DLCs, particularly The Old Gods, are genuinely fun. I love playing as the Norse during the Age of the Vikings and it's honestly one of the best parts of the game. It's to the point I almost wish The Old Gods was spun off as a different game (similar to For the Glory) to focus on just that era and expand more into Viking clans, religion, etc.
-Unlike most I've played Crusader Kings 1 extensively and while there are a lot of steps back from that game, I do like that the council does more than just improve ruler stats. Letting your council micro-manage your realm (before they ruined it with Conclave) is genuinely very fun and makes it feel more like an actual feudal state.
-It got me, someone who doesn't really like video games enough to be called a gamer" (most of the games on my Steam are gifts are stuff I bought and never played)
date:
to play for 200 hours so that's got to count for something.

reviewText:
I painstakingly micromanaged my first born son's education, choosing his educators and rotating them to ensure he got a well-rounded education.

When he turned 16, his attributes were solid, particularly in martial. My warrior son will lead my empire into the next generation!

Then, I saw that he was gay.

Not a big deal. My gay warrior son will lead my empire into the next generation! So, I got him a wife, hopefully to make him forget men.

It seemed to work. Just a while later he asked to join the Varingian Guard. I gave him my blessing. My gay warrior son will fight heathens and in killing them forget about men.

Two years later he returned to me. He was blinded and castrated. My gay warrior son was now mutilated and a eunech. I ordered him to take his vows and he quietly lived out his years in a monastery without eyes or gonads.

My second born son will lead my empire into the next generation!
