reviewText:
The first thing I did as the King of England was assassinate the King of Scotland. It wasn’t for any particular reason. I had just started running the game for the first time, and wanted to check out the King of where I actually lived. But then I saw the assassinate button. I pressed the assassinate button. There was suddenly a dead Scottish monarch and a massive civil war.
Crusader Kings II is a ‘Grand Strategy Game’ by Paradox Entertainment, a lovingly created, complex board game of Europe, where you play as historical character. Unlike other strategy games, where you’re the godly hand that guides a country or force, here you’re a Count, Duke, King or Emperor, with all the extra complexities and joys that brings. You have to handle your lineage – marry, have children, assassinate children, change succession laws – so that the game continues. It is the only must in CKII: create an heir, or on death without one, it’s game over. The rest is really up to you. You could try and forge the Empire of Hispania as one of the Spanish Catholic kings, unifying the other catholic nations there and driving out the Muslim rulers. You could play peacefully as the King of Scotland in a different game, only stooping to war when vassals rebel for their own claims on your kingdom. With certain DLC, you could play as Muslim rulers in Africa and Saudi Arabia, Pagan rulers, or even as a patrician, vying for control of the sea highways and port to get the most profit possible.

The board deserves some explanation also: unlike many other strategy games, which use hexagonal or square tiles, here real counties are used, such as Gowrie, Cumberland, Middlesex, Badajoz, Leon, and Maine. And they aren’t just bits of land to get to make your Kingdom look bigger: they hold cities, castles and religious buildings that will increase the size of you or your vassal’s levies (army) when annexed and your income, from tax. You can even improve and build new holdings in these counties, to increase both of these. This is one of the many ways you spend your gold, along with creating kingdoms and duchies, hiring mercenaries, bribing the pope (yup!), assassinations, ect.

Though out the game, you will be collecting this gold from the taxes, which is the commodity you will be using most often. Also throughout your characters life, he’ll gain Prestige and Piety: both add to your end game score, which you can use to measure just how well you’ve done after playing all those hundreds of years. Both also act like currencies, with you gaining prestige and piety from certain wars and events, but losing them with other events such as destroying kingdom titles (prestige), creating empire and kingdoms (piety) and reforming pagan religions (piety). Upon your characters death, they add to your score – not, however, a reason to die early.

War is enjoyable in Crusader Kings II, but possibly not as important as in other strategy games. You can’t declare war, willy nilly. You must have a cause for war, the ‘cassus belli’. This at first feels very restrictive, as in some catholic countries, the only clear way to expand into neighbouring catholic nations is through the slow fabrication of a claim on the county. But eventually it blossoms into the complex strategy, as you juggle where to war with, with what cassus belli, to what end. It becomes delightfully full of opportunities. The Catholic Kingdoms can declare Holy Wars against Pagans and Muslims and claim their land, along with participating in the Crusades the Pope occasionally calls. You also have ‘De Jure Claims’, where you can conquer counties and land that belongs to the predefined ‘de jure’ duchies, kingdoms and empires, depending if you are a Duke, King or Emperor. Pagans can conquer any bordering counties, or subjugate entire kingdoms once in a life time. There is a treasure trove of reasons to war. And with your army, you can choose who leads the armies, and whether to engage them in battles against other armies, or to siege enemy provinces in the war. But it isn’t the only way to gain land: ensuring you’re the heir to the kingdom through assassinations and plots; through offering vassalization to the weaker, smaller independent rulers nearby. But wars are one of the more enjoyable points in the game, as long as you know how to handle them. There really is no better feeling than slowly building your independent duchy into a sprawling Empire over the years.

It is important to say that all the rulers on the map are actively acting towards their own goals, with the games superb AI letting hundreds of characters act and change Europe, even in places far from where you are playing. It is sometimes enjoyable to pause the game, and just look around the map, at what’s happening far away. Seeing distant kingdoms fracture, far of empires grow, really gives the game a sense of scale that is great.

And in multiplayer, you can have friends play in any of the Kingdoms, replacing one of the AI rulers. It can be incredible fun, with you playing as different Kingdoms, competing as you expand. You can choose whatever way you want to play with friends – you can assassinate them, declare war on them, or offer to join their wars. If they play as the same culture or religion, you may want to help them, to spread it, or fulfil goals that will help you all. With me and a friend playing Norse Pagans (Old Gods DLC), we started trying to expand my kingdom so that it controlled enough holy sites to reform the religion and grant us much needed security for successions. We’ve also had to aid each other during widespread civil and international war and bail each other out. It’s incredibly satisfying to bail your friends’ kingdom out of an independence war, and know they owe you one when you want to take over a nearby kingdom.

The downsides of the game is the initial bafflement due to the complexities of how to combine all the systems for your own benefit, and the occasionally irritation caused by wars for the kingdom after succession. Multiplayer also requires all other players must download the host save file every time they play, which can be a slow, but is thankfully all handled in game.
This game is one for those who wish to carve a story and a kingdom out of Europe, and are willing to learn through all the complexities and systems to do so. Once the game finally clicks and you’re away with it, it really is a magnificent game. Whole heartedly recommended.

reviewText: Crusader Kings II isn't a game, it's a lifestyle.

reviewText:
Coming from games like the Total War series or the Civilization games, you might notice similarities to both at once. Think Medieval Total War played completely on the overview map but injected with a touch of Civs intrigue and a lot more provinces/factions.

But that is barely, if ever scratching the surface. If you are a fan of Game of Thrones court politics or a history buff interested in having his own alternate timeline sandbox to play in, you are right at home.

Want to be an English duke who sleeps with the king's wife and then assassinates said king to inherit his realm? You can do that.
Want to start as a Hindu Indian raja and expand all the way to the Mediterranean while crushing the Arab Empire? You can do that.
Want to be an ambitious Norse pagan in Scandinavia who amasses enough men to conquer Britain and impose the worship of Odin on all of Europe? You can do that too.
Want to be a Zoroastrian prince in the Asian steppes who marries the princess of another khan but also has a b:astard son he got with his own sister? Guess what? Fair game.

Before said description drives you to buy everything, be forewarned.
1.If this is your first grand strategy game, you have a bit of a steep learning curve in the beginning that, once surpassed, simply makes the game click".  I absolutely recommend a must watch tutorial by Arumba on Youtube that does a far better job explaining stuff than the otherwise solid in game tutorial. You also might want to start as an Irish count in 1066 to get a hang of the game mechanics.
2. The base game has come a long way since launch and you can have a solid amount of fun with just it in your library. But the meat of the game and the huge range of choices is locked behind DLC. That wouldn't be too much of an issue if there weren't so many of them. I would absolutely not recommend paying full price for everything - sales are your friends as they usually group a bunch of DLC together for a fair price. You also don't need many of the flavour DLC.
If you do buy the base game and decide to get the DLC gradually and later
date: for the safety of your wallet and for the biggest wealth of content
recommended: two are a must and are not expensive in sales - Sword of Islam and the Old Gods. Both unlock previously unplayable factions (aside from India) and Old Gods gives you an earlier starting date in the 9th century which many consider the best one (I tend to agree as Charlemaigne

reviewText:
It's just awesome!

This is one of the best game I've ever played so far.
It's a strategy game in real time with the pause button :-)
It's a sandbox game though there aren't specific targets, but you have to set your own goals, but you'll find yourself reviewing them continously adapting your strategy to either planned or unexpected events.

In the game it's well represented the feudal system of the middle age, though you can start playing as Count, Duke, King or Emperor and therefore ramp up and grow your domain size caring about relationships within your own realm, your vassals and the court members, but also building alliances with other rulers via weddings.

When you start a new campaign, you pick a ruler between 1066 and 1421 (Christians in vanilla, other rulers unlockable via DLCs like muslims, sea republics and pagans) and the target is to make your dinasty becoming more and more powerful. It's possible to start from 867 with The Old Gods" DLC.

You're noble then you should manage only castles or county having a castle in the capital (you could play as mayor if you have The Republics DLC).

reviewText:
This is something of a Gateway game to take people into the genre of Grand Strategy games in my opinion, starting you in the place of a feudal lord, merchant republic patrician or as a pagan seeking to reform their faith. I think variety is one of the most important aspects in a game and this game provides hells amount of variety and then some. The scenario is constantly changing, and I literally mean constantly changing as feudal lords die, and new rulers take their place and wars coming from the thin of air to turn the balance in their favor.

The game is complicated to grasp at first, and requires some dedication and willpower to see through the initial shock of all the concepts, but it can very much be compared to team fortress and all the new weapons and learning things bit by bit. Same concept of learning, and if you ever master this game there will always be Europa Universalis IV to move onto with the save converter, or if you're feeling bold, Victoria 2.

Start your character fresh with ruler designer with only yourself to expand it, and in two hundred years it could become THE leading dynasty. Pick up the Old gods and take the Norse sons of Ragnar and conquer Scandanavia and maybe even Britannia, France and the Holy Roman Empire. This is the game where you aren't restricted by anything, and in a series where alternate history is the norm.

Edit: My only concern is that much of the game is locked away under DLC. While I love supporting a developer like Paradox I think I should also offer warning that playing without any expansions will limit much of your variety. I started playing the game when it originally came out and bought the DLC as they came out, but the price will seem daunting to those coming into the game. If you're just coming into the game without knowing anything, I'd recommend grabbing two DLCs in particular: The Old Gods and The Legacy of Rome.""

reviewText:
RIP in pieces CK2.  It was a good 4 years!

Conclave patch ruined the game.  Buy and downgrade or DON'T BUY IT AT ALL.  Better yet, huehue, you know what to do. Whatever you actually decide to do, don't reward them for trashing one of the greatest strategy games ever made with the latest patch.  It's absolutely garbage in every way, from destroying the war score system to implementing extremely imbalanced laws, EVEN if you don't buy conclave, you'll still have that horrible patch ruining the game.  Oh yeah, they actually introduced coalitions into CK2 LOL.  THIS ISN'T EU4 YOU SILLY PEOPLE. WHY ARE YOU DEVELOPING THIS LIKE EU4? URGGGGHH.

For the love of God, do not buy this broken game as it is.  DO NOT reward them for making extremely terrible design decisions and implementation.  If you must, downgrade and find old mod versions that are compatible with the last patch.  CK2 IS DEAD.

P.S. I realize I don't sound like the most rational human being in the world.  But coming from someone with 775 hrs in the game and even more on another account, they REALLY, REALLY, REALLY messed things up this patch.  Not only that but they're also nickel and diming you for every f-ing update.  They actually released an additional CONTENT PACK for the newest dlc, conclave.  I mean, seriously, they actually did that.  /endrant

tl;dr, they done goofed and ruined ck2.  if you buy, figure out how to revert back to an older patch and if you want mods, figure out which previous mod versions you'll need to run on the old patch. gg paradox.

reviewText:
While I love this game and have played it more than any other game in my entire life, I am nonetheless extremely disappointed with the Conclave DLC. The funny thing is, I haven't even purchased it - meaning I can't put my review on its page - but parts of it have still seeped into my game anyway.

Shattered retreat is complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and does nothing except pointlessly prolong already one-sided wars. The decreased opinion bonuses from vassals make them a hundred times more of a pain in the ♥♥♥, and they seem to remain in factions against me even when their opinion of me is extremely high. I've heard plenty of other complaints about the proper DLC as well, like ruining the child education system and making the council as reasonable as a brick wall.

It's unfortunate, really. This is such a great game, but this DLC has accentuated everything I didn't like about it and added virtually nothing in return. I can't imagine what Paradox was smoking when they made this, but until they get their act together, I can't recommend a purchase.

reviewText: Crusader Kings II.  If I could choose only one strategy game to bring with me to a lonely desert island it would be this one.  The amount of content is insane (with new content being offered every few months), the updates are frequent, and the game play itself is extremely deep and rewarding.  There are time when I get the urge to play and I refuse to allow myself to because I know that if I start up another game I'll be playing it for the vast majority of my free time for the next several weeks.\n\nThe game has so much to it that I couldn't even begin to do it justice without writing a ten page paper so I'll leave it at this: if you're a fan of strategy games, get this one!

reviewText:
I learned a lot of geography from this game and EU IV.

Seriously, come trivia night, my geography is really on point. Capitals, country locations, rivers, I know that stuff.

Which is nice.

This may be the most complete and well rounded historical simulator available, and its mechanics are unique without being gimmicky. You see CK2 is about forging a dynasty, which is a fancy way of saying a rules heavy family. It's technically sandbox and you can have quite a bit of fun with it. You can roleplay as the traits that you have, or just try to make every character into Julius Caesar, or just keep assasinating popes, forever and ever. When your character dies, whether it be at 4 or 88, the play goes to the direct heir, whether he or she be 4 or 88, and you are given control over their decision making process.

As long as your dynasty has not died out in terms of inheritance laws, and someone in your dynasty has a sufficient title the game will continue until it stops after maybe dozens or a hundred hours of game play. You manage titles under your realm. Count is the lowest, than Duchy, than King, than Emperor, with some variety on the names depending on your culture. The key here is feudalism, that is vassalage. The standard is to pledge fealty to someone of the next higher title, who then pledges fealty to the title above them. This standard is never reached unless you conquer the world and make it be reached. In general, there will be sovereign Dukes, Counts pledged directly to Kings, and Emperors often forgo vassal kings.

You have advisers which are assigned from your court,  which is a pool of loyal or disloyal followers whom you can consider for various roles, and to accomplish various tasks. These advisers assist you in running the operations of your feifdom, and allow religious, educational, espionage, stewardship, and martial decisions. Each character has an RPG style stat for each of these, and these along with a portion of your wife's stats and your advisers stats creates the stats used in game for you.

Key decisions in this game are marriage, and war. Marriage is the influence you have over your dynasty, and you can get good traits, titles, claims on titles, or political alliances in exchange for the matrimony. Wars allow you to cement alliances and shape the geopolitical landscape. There is much more to the game, as it has surprising complexity, but this is not to be a guide.

The game is visually very appealing, despite largely being a giant map. The music is nice, and even after several hours you may not be bored. There is also a ton of DLC for this, for better or worse. These are largely all expansive on the game, and most will be on for most games. Some like the Sunset Invasion are cheesy alternative history which you likely will not want on at all times. There are an absurd number of starting rulers at any of a number of initial scenarios, and a bit of imagination makes all interactions fun as you write your own story of world history amongst the players who have interesting personalities derived from their traits. This game remains an absolute treasure, and is still updated from time to time.

reviewText: Where to begin.. I'll begin with the bad. This developer is probably the most guilty of nickle and diming it's customers for DLC. Just look at the price tag of this game 159 USD?? I'm sorry, but no game no matter how good it may or may not be is not worth such a price tag.  So, no I would never recomend this game, nor any game made by Paradox due to it's policy of overpricing, and diving small bits and bobs they've released later after the initial release of the game when they should have bundled most of the dlc available into a proper expansion pack as an honest game developer would instead of taking advantage of the consumer.                    The base game is good enough, the graphics aren't great but not everyone is worried about that. It's good strategy fun but at such a price, no. Do not buy this game, it's only driving prices for our games higher and higher, its bad for the industry and even worse for the consumer.

reviewText:
I would have recommended this game right until the most recent patch. Expanding into an empire becomes nearly impossible as you try and fight off the entire planet in a holy war for one county.

The recently added coalition feature might not be a bad idea but its implementantion is appalling. After pressing your claims on a neighbouring area (be that be a county, duchy or kingdom) you find yourself in a similar situation as 1938 Nazi germany. The whole world hates you and is ready to start a world war at a moments notice. The pope will join muslims and pagans alike in this global war against you (despite the fact you are a devout christian) and you will soon find yourself fighting on 4000 fronts at once in a war for a SINGLE province. Rather silly.

Do not buy this game in its current state.

reviewText: This game is awesome. Start out as a little guy in Ireland and become the Emperor of the British Isles, and then lose it all in a generation and you're a count again. Except this time you're a count somewhere in Germany because on a previous character you married some German count's daughter, and he had a feud with someone who murdered all of his sons and you ended up inheriting it. Well now I guess you're in Germany so you start all over again. You fabricate some claims, and invite some claimants and land them, allowing you to take land for them that will be added to your overall realm. Eventually you're big enough and you've bribed enough people that you manage to get yourself elected Holy Roman Empire. Now the might of the Reich is going to go down upon that upstart Duke who thought he could overthrow you as Emperor of Britain.\n\nEvery game can be this interesting. Try it.

reviewText:
Crusader Kings II is a great starting point for anyone who's been looking to get into the grand strategy genre but has been overwhelmed by Paradox's previous titles. Fairly easy to learn, and with all the gameplay improvement and alternative history mods, you'll get plenty of time for your money.

As someone who's played over 500 hours in Deus Vult, I did find it a little disappointing that Ck2 didn't inflict the same amount of ungodly punishment that the previous games did; One of the best experiences in Deus Vult was getting beat down constantly and getting back up, but I'll be the first to admit it was probably for the best. Ironman is a very interesting feature that suffers slightly from the constant autosaving disrupting gameplay, but this may not be such a big issue if you have a good computer that autosaves quickly.

Now one major concern is the unending horde of DLC. I really don't approve of the direction Paradox Interactive is going with their DLC for Ck2, paying for historical dynasty shields? Ehhhh.

The game is priced at $40
To get all the major DLC's (Expansions) alone costs $55

As It stands, CK2 is not worth buying full price. Wait for a sale where the collection is 75% off and grab it.

reviewText:
This is essentially Game Of Thrones: the game.

In my first game, I played as an Irish ruler, and got him married to an English lady to cement an alliance, allowing me to begin a conquest of Ireland. My wife proceeded to bear me daughter after daughter, which due to the country's male inheritance laws left my vassals unhappy.

Then, her father dies and she is left as his heir - she returns to her home county in England. Whilst there she bears two more daughters (seven in total now!), which seemed a bit off with me as how can she have my children when in another country?

It emerges that she was sleeping with a local Bishop. I realise I need a new wife if I'm to ever have a male heir, yet I can't divorce her or I'll end up making enemies of the English. So, I start a plot to assassinate her.

The very first person who offers their help with killing her? The bishop she was sleeping with! And he'll be most valuable, having lots of access" to her! My plot is in motion!

And then
date: said Bishop gets royally drunk and blabs about the entire thing to everyone
voteText: and I have a troop of daughters at my ankles.\n\nDamn fun game

reviewText:
Was playing online with friend. Seduced friends wife but got caught in the act. Friend castrated me as a punishment. 10/10 would give friends wife syphilis again.

It should be called Walder Frey simulator 2014. Seriously everyone seems to get assassinated at weddings, your spy master is constantly telling you that people are homosexual and you should execute them, your wife is trying to kill you for no reason at all, your 4 year old daughter is married to a 62 year old dwarf from northern Africa, everyone is in incestuous relationships, and you have no idea what is going on. 10/10 game!

At first a lot of people are put off by the presentation of this game (those who don't play Paradox Grand Strategy Games that is). The closest the majority of gamers (apologies for the generalisation) have gotten to a strategy game is Total War, Age of Empires or Civilisation; games that keep their audiences interested by dumbing down the complexities and keeping audiences hooked with visual entertainment through battle sequences (Please note, I am not criticising; I am a huge fan of these games).

CK2 on the other hand is a colourful map, on first viewing, at best. This is a game that, at first glance - and I'm extending that time period out to your first 2-4 hours with it - seems like a cold, number-driven strategy game. Something only grognards can enjoy, in between tabletop wargame sessions and forum arguments over the finer points of Napoleon's invasion of Russia.

And to be fair to first glances, it is. This is a Paradox grand strategy game, one that doesn't just crunch numbers, it grinds them to dust, sprinkles them across 11,715 buttons and menu options and feasts on them. It's an intimidating game to come to grips with, in no small part because Paradox are so terrible at tutorials, and almost as bad at creating intuitive user interfaces.

Stick with it, though, and my. Oh my. What begins as a blind exercise in clicking things and getting your ♥♥♥ kicked all over Europe slowly begins to blossom. You start to realise what those little lustful" and "deceitful" character traits on every character mean. You realise that the marriage system is an entire mechanic built into the game
date: not some pointless piece of window dressing. It clicks that
hoursPlayed: the game is populated by every single noble
voteText: religious figure and courtier across Europe (and most of the Middle East).\n\nIn short
helpfulPercent: you realise that this isn't a game about war
votesHelpful: or empires
votesTotal: or money
votesFunny:
or some pre-anointed goal you must achieve to be the "winner".

It's a game about people. And the relationships between them.

So why is it so addicting? That's simple

reviewText:
I love this game. The systems and mechanics seem to be balanced perfectly for emergent narrative. While the strategy is awesome, I find the best part of this game is the stories that develop from those systems.

The depth is amazing. I’ve played over 100 hours now and have only really played one full game, and 2 half games. My first Ironman game (no loading saves) I started as Denmark. I managed gained Norway, but lost it despite assassinating tens of people in the succession line ahead of my heir. I made inroads into Sweden before taking it entirely (after the then King got taken down by a mercenary army), then married my way onto the throne of Lotharingia and used my new power to take Pomerania - in the process becoming the most powerful ruler in the Holy Roman Empire. I demanded independence from the Holy Roman Emperor who buckled before me, splitting the Empire in two. I basked in glory for several decades (holding several feasts and tournaments) before a massive continental war spanning over ten years, during which my successor lost control of Lotharingia and Pomerania. Once the dust cleared, I had to settle for being Queen of Sweden and Denmark.

But you don't mind stuff like that happening - playing a count or a duke can be as much fun (and way less stressful) than being a King or an Emperor. I held onto those two kingdoms while gaining Finland, before marrying the Kaiserin of the Holy Roman Empire! Everything was coming up Chris, but then she sadly died in childbirth - leaving my son as the Kaiser.

Comparisons to game of thrones in game form are not far off, in fact there is a mod (I haven't tried) and like GOT there is absolutely no guarantees of a happy ending. In my game I managed to become the Kaiser and clung grimly to the throne until the end of the game. All that in just one game - and I haven't even got the latest expansion yet, which adds India.

The multiplayer is great too, playing with a friend means you can work together and there is someone there to enjoy the narrative with you, and leads you to great stuff like marrying your buddy (in the game) and then cheating on them. Or making them your Master of the Hunt.

One complaint would be the learning curve, in that I had no idea what I was doing for the first 20 or so hours. Also periods (years sometimes) can go by with not a lot happening, but I just speed it up in those instances. Once you invest 25 or so hours into learning the game, the rewards are amazing.

reviewText:
The title Crusader Kings 2 falls under the so-called grand-strategy games. The term is well-earned in this case and before you start the game be warned that there is a steep learning curve. Do not pick up this game if long-winded games that requires hours of hours to finish is not your thing. Do pick it up if you like games like Civilization, Alpha Centauri, or Europe Universalis. Having said that, and perhaps you do not know these titles, lets get into what Crusader Kings 2 actually is.

Like all grand-strategy games Crusader Kings 2 is (but need not be, I will get back to this) for instance about creating a dukedom, kingdom, or empire, keeping those under you happy less they revolt, and creating a proper army. Unlike many other grand strategy games (outside of other Paradox titles) this game is actually historically correct for medieval europe, the middle east, and India. That is right, did you ever want to play as William the Conquerer? This game gives you that opportunity.

That immediatly leads to 'need not be' clasule I said before. Unlike other grand strategy games you do not play a 'faction' or a 'nation', but you play as an individuel e.g. Ghengis Khan. The game doesn't end when you die, however, no it follows the rise (and fall) of your family as your dominion grows on the map. Depending on your succesion laws you might be playing as your oldest, youngest, or even a random family member. You might even go super modern and have daughters rule on purpose, not 'just because' the male line ended as was more the case in the time period between 769-1452 AD (which how long the games played out assuming you have two DLCs).

The game features cultures (e.g. German, Anglo-Saxon, Berber, Russian, Visigothic, and Tamil) as well as religions (e.g. Hindu, Catholic, Coptic, Karasite, Tengri, Sunni, and Germanic) and this including with recently conquered, traits of a person, your history with them perhaps, can all influence what people think of you. Wil you marry out a daughter for an alliance, or perhaps with that genius of a man so you can get him to court and get a good advisor? This is all dependent upon you.

Thanks to all these features, as well as the fact that once the game starts randomness kicks in and the historical accurate timeline is lost, means that you will never(!) play the same game ever again. Mechanics wise yes, but give it enough time and the map will look quiet different from last time, different kings and emperors, and perhaps e.g. the Byzantine empire might have fallen by 1100. What will you do? How will you influence medieval Europe? I say it is time to find out and play Crusader Kings 2 for yourself.

reviewText:
Backstab, fight, talk and murder your way to victory.

Wow, just wow.

Another hit title by Paradox, an almost certain must buy! Launch yourself into an immersive, and ever changing campaign, spanning over 500 years (providing you have the Old Gods DLC).

Ever wanted to be King of England? Kaiser of the Holy Roman Empire? Or simply wanted to be a low-lying Baron? Look no further, Crusader Kings II is for you! Crusader Kings II is certainly one of the best Paradox games out there, with a whole new gameplay interface. If games like Victoria II and Europa annoyed you because the lack of character interaction, Crusader Kings II is perfect to settle that fetish of yours.

Dive into the famous Godwin family in 1066, and try fight of the Norse hordes, and the Norman aggressors, or make your own House (with the ruler designer DLC), and help it rise into the anals of history. CKII has an in-depth system of character interaction, where you can do anything from sending them a gift, assassinating them, offering them vassalage, or organising a marrage, anything is possible in CkII.

Buy this game, all it's DLCs, and get lost in the (almost) never-ending and ever-changing campaign, which will get you hooked from day 1, to the end-day.

Enjoy!

reviewText:
One of the best grand strategy games of all times. When CK II appeared on steam was pretty much sceptical about it, but when i started to watch Northernlion's LP series i was into this game. CK II is not easy strategy game, however learning curve is quite interesting, and only will learn by trial and error as it requires to be patience. Learn to manage your county. Succeeded? Now it's time to rule as Duke or Duchess. Try plotting, scheming, bribing. Change your succession law and crown authority. Slay anyone who stands against Catholic religion, start Holy war against heretics and expand your realm.
As for multiplayer, it is great feature because it allows you to play with friends and do whatever you want either coop till end of time or play against each other.

Score: 10/10.

reviewText:
CKII is truly one of the finest strategy games out there. If you put in the time to get the most out of it, you will be rewarded with a deep and complex game which has endless replay value.

The sense of accomplishment you can get from conquering the Holy Land, or reforming the Roman Empire, or inheriting a kingdom after decades of plotting, or simply painting the entire map your colour, is nothing quite like any other game out there.

If you want the full range of experiences you will want the DLC which add new features and unlock previously unplayable characters, but even without this CKII provides a gaming experience you won't be quick to leave behind.

reviewText:
While truly there are lots of things to enjoy about CK2, and everyone finds his own most favourite part in this game, I personally find the stories it creates the most exciting part about it. For example, this story happened just yesterday.

One day my character was chilling in a carriage in his old family lands in Hungary when suddenly he was ambushed and taken prisoner by some weirdo in Brittany. The freak tortured my character with rats. What is worse, I had no money to buy my way out of the prison. At the same time, my lovely new wife became pregnant, and, for obvious reasons, this could not be my character's child. After the first daughter came the second and only then my unwitty spymaster uncovered that the weird guy and my unfaithful wife had an affair! Sadly, due to my liege's incompetency in managing the realm, my lands were constantly pillaged by vicious pagan tribes, leaving me with almost no income. Moreover, the regent that was installed to rule in my character's place was a nice and a charitable guy. He shared all of my petty income with the starving and underprivileged. He did not like my character either and never agreed to anything I have asked him to do.

My poor character ended up in a dark and cold oubliette after his friend tried to rescue him and failed. He soon passed away, betrayed by everyone. He only needed 20 more gold coins to buy his way out...

Soon after the news reached Hungary, king's brother was selected as the new king. Being an envious, lustful and ambitious fellow, he always found his brother's wife to be prettier and more attractive than his own. He immediately divorced and married the unfaithful widow. A few months later, the new king decided to relieve his stress by embarking on a carriage trip to his old family's lands, when suddenly they were stopped on a road by a group of french-speaking hoodlums...

reviewText:
This game's learning curve is not just steep... the tutorial is garbage and only slightly grazes the major aspects of the game (it doesn't go into any of the in-depth mechanics that the game so notably advertises about, and it definetly doesn't do a good job at teaching how to play).

I play all genres of games and am used to learning strange and odd game mechanics.  I am 30 years old and have been gaming since the original Atari console.  When I read reviews about this game I wasn't phased by everyone saying the learning curve was steep.  I have owned mostly every major game console released, as well as have played a few years worth of game hours in PC games.

On top of that, I have played dungeons and dragons (the dice version with a DM/GM), I have played text-based games such as the original kings quest... I have played many board games, book games, card games... etc... What I am trying to allude to is that I am an experienced gamer with above-average technical and troubleshooting abilities; usually I am the one my friends go to when they need help with figuring something out.

I have spent close to 3 hours in the game and still feel I have no control over what is going on within the game, nor do I feel I have a solid grasp on how to gain control over what is going on within the game.  I understand not being able to just pick up a game and master it... but 3 hours is too long to spend in a game to still be constantly feeling at a loss in trying to do something and not being able to do it.  I can play the game, but I in-no-way enjoy constantly feeling frustrated because I'm trying to do something that I can not do.

I no longer have the time I had when I was younger to play games, so when I play a game, I want to enjoy it.  I feel I would need to invest a minimum of 10 hours into this game, just to have a solid grasp on how to play it.  That is too much for me, considering most modern non-rpg games can be beaten in less than 10 game-hours.

I'm not saying I'm not willing to invest hours into a game, as I've invested close to 120 game-hours into some of my games... but I have searched for more reviews and people, like me, have also had major difficulties in understanding how to manipulate the game (even when some people who are experienced in playing the game helping them).

For me... with the horrible tutorial... the insanely large amount of buy in" time required to learn the game... this game just isn't worth it.  There are many easier-to-play and more in-depth games out there similar to this."

reviewText:
This game down to it's core is politics at its basest form. ♥♥♥ kissing the powerful and the many while plotting to become the powerful. It's also  a very archaic form of politics since current politics only ♥♥♥ kisses the powerful.

This game is a ♥♥♥♥♥ to get used to, I personally had a lot trouble getting into it. But give it enough time and you'll find it quite simple and even 150+ hours in I'm still learning a few extra tricks to give me more advantages. Another thing you might find daunting is all the DLC and there is a LOT of DLC, it will give you a lot more hours and I mean a LOT more hours of gametime as you play the different types of religions/governments.

It also remains quite true to how large kingdoms and empires were run. The bigger they got the weaker the ruler at the top got, since you have to appease all your vassals and pray they start a revolt that you can put down.

If you're not sure if you want to play this game there is a demo available, so you don't have to take a gamble with this game.

Now I shall get back to kissing the asses of all my vassals!

reviewText:
THE MEDIEVALSIMS
Features:+++ HISTORY/GEOGRAPHY CLASSES WHILE PLAYING!+++ Community Driven DLCs and MODs.++ Grand Strategy of medieval europe sim.++ Tons of thousands of features and highly moddable.++ GAME OF THRONES MOD.+- Gets boring after reaching empire from scratch (but they will revolt, surely).
Grand strategy political micromanagement game, you will understand that Arbitrary Rulers can do whatever the hell they think they want. Sending roses for a neighbor, ending up taking care of the garden.

Marriages for political reasons, alliances because the enemy of my enemy is my friend, duchies stronger than kingdons, kingdons that might rise out of nowhere, you will learn that family members are actually your worst enemies (not that different from nowadays I think) and you will lose battles, win wars, learn how grateful you were for making friends, and how stupid you were for not realizing someone else's friends are really powerful.

Educate your brood, rule over the vulnerable, offer protection and prey on the weak, intrigue and plot over claims, create claims with your court, become a paragon of virtue and control a religion, call holy wars on infidels, kill your enemy on battle, kill your enemy on an ambush, become friends with your fellow neighbors, walk the lands as looters for money and supplies.

Spread your dynasty around the world, spread your seed around, deal with invasions from the west, invasions from the east, revolts, religious zealots with massive armies spreading havock over your lands, learn that the real use of religion is for politics, learn that children can be conditioned.

Change history, create empires, destroy mighty foes, rise the ladder of the prestige, be envied by your enemies, die in the annals of nowhere, if you become incapable watch as your regent push laws and change things as he sees fit.

Play online with your friends, same kingdom or different kingdoms, be kind and deceitful, be cruel but just, be a jerk, be a leader, be yourself, be your character but always remember: Real world will never be the same once the feudal knowledge affects your judgement.

This game is a training for fatherhood.

Also, watch out for the Game of Thrones MOD.

reviewText:
Where do I start. This game is addictive as all hell. It is a pure character role play orientated game where you play generation from generation of your family throughout the dark ages with everything revolving around how YOU as the player mould your character and his/her successors. This does mean that a single playthrough from just 1066 to 1453 can take in the excess of sevral days.

Have you ever wanted to play as a Spaniard with Russian culture who is a staunch believer of the Zoroastrian faith and conquer Germany? In this game, you can! That is just the tip off the iceberg of insanity. I have had a succession war with my 1st born son who was also the SPAWN OF SATAN, literally a hell baby.

Now understand this game can be daunting to new players especially because there are no real good tutorials provided by the game. That is definitely a shortfall and has to be made up with Youtube tutorials or experienced friends who play the game. The other problem is how random some events can be which can royally screw over a fresh game. I wont go into details but I am sure many of my fellow players can recount situations the destroyed their games. Also It pretty much a requirement to get game mechanic DLC such as Old Gods and the Republic to get the most out of the game.

That is the only real problems I can think of with the game. Otherwise its an excellent game with challenges and character driven role play. Fantastic modding community always re-inventing the game and extending the hours of life this game has. I don’t think this game can be adequately compared to any other just because how unique it is.

I rate this game 11/10

reviewText:
This game will hate you. It will leap up and slap you in the face. And as a result, you will never want to leave its side.

As a wise man once said: Life has no Ctrl 'Z'.

A great many things are beyond your control, unusual in a strategy game but far more true to reality.



Perhaps you will pause in your travels at a tavern, nurse a cool ale, and the tavern will explode, killing you instantly.

Son of a... Is nothing sacred?

Or maybe your favourite son will take over as regent when you grow old and decrepit, only to steal all your titles and imprison you.

Bet you're regreting your refusal to aid your brother in killing the little sod now, aren't you?

Perhaps you become just another in a long line to die from Medieval Europe's most dangerous plague - 'Suspicious circumstances'?

It's never entirely clear how suspicious they are, or what you're supposed to do about it, but you know what they say - Life's a female dog.

Or maybe, at the ripe old age of 84 you'll die from syphillis.

Irritating it might be, but you'll be unable to fight the surge of pride that you were still getting it on at an age when most men's fading eyesight ensures they can't even see the appropriate body parts any more.

And the list goes on: vassals tearing your Empires apart, mobs killing your tax collectors, rioting zealots, crusades, becoming blinded, castrated, imprisoned, diseased, incapable, having your son born the anti-christ, or, god forbid, losing your favourite hunting hound (why, why, oh cruel, wretched world?).

CK2 will punish you, and you will love every second of it, because when you do manage to pull everything together, nothing in life will bring you more joy.

Not since Firefly has anything been more deserving of the tagline 'Someone ever tries to kill you, you try to kill 'em right back.'

reviewText: This game basically runs like a diplomacy simulator, enabling the player to build their own dynasty the way they want it to be. With an array of different options at your disposal, and a citizenry to keep happy, Crusader Kings can present a challenge. Using Historical time periods and even historical heads of state, The appeal of Crusader Kings 2 moves beyond lovers of Diplomacy games. Dealing with Heir's, Vassals, and underhanded siblings, Crusader Kings allows you to micromanage your dynasty, enabling a player to give their line a personal touch. I don't typically go for these types of games, but in fairness, it is fairly well done and offers a lot of playability options so I have to recommend it if that is the kind of game you enjoy.

reviewText: Crusader Kings 2 is the campaign of Total War, set to focus not on a nation, but on a family.  Your house must become as powerful as possible, this involves a lot of political manipulation and throwing money around.  As I say, the game is the campaign - there is no real control over your battles like in Total War, what you enter the fight with is all that contributes to your victory.  That is a shame, hopefully by the time Paradox decides to do Crusader Kings 3, they'll have worked up the nerve to go for it.\n\nWhile I cannot recommend the game to every type of strategy game fan, this one has been a lot of fun for me, and has presented me with a lot of challenges.

I personally think Paradox's DLC model on this is very unethical and would not reccomend this game to anybody who wanted a full game for a reasonable price. Paradox seems to have gotten better with this, as EUIV has a DLC model that allows a full gameplay experience without DLC, but the DLC enhance it, but this is just a demo to make you want to buy dlc.

reviewText:
Crusader Kings II is a Grand Strategy game based around familiy dynasties, political power mongering and in short - trying to make sure you have the biggest wealthest family in the world. The game spans ~400 years of historical time between 1066 to 1453 and offers historical events and references that you can either choose to follow or create a new alternantive timeline from. Do you start a 'War of the Roses' battle? Does YOUR family takeover the Papal?

Building relationships, marriages, alliances and faking claims is the key. If this sounds all very Game of Thrones then you're right - it is. Crusader Kings II is the best GoT game on the market at the moment, and that's all thanks to engine being used.

Crusader Kings II is the end result of many years of creating and improving on Paradox's Clausewitz Engine (the engine responsible for Cruaders Kings, Europa Universalis, Hearts of Iron franchises). If you're familiar with those games, you might feel familiar with CK2, but the truth is this game goes beyond what the engine has produced before hand.
The Clausewitz Engine is in sense the major selling point behind CK2, so while the graphics aren't anything special (and are little more than 3D Marker Pieces) the true beauty unfolds as you play.
I can't think of many greater feelings than the moment you're 50 year plotting to get your Grandson into place of power from his lowly Duke title to Lord pays off. Sending your Master of Whispers into a neighbouring region to spread lies and cause dissent amongst the vassals, while you forge a plot to fabricate claims to the title and ursurp the Lordship. So good.

Paradox have managed to support the game well since release in the form of DLC Expansions, which have opened the game world up and expanded the 'fringe' empires to be just as complex as the 'key' European ones. However they've also supported the game with post-release patching and balancing, so they're not ones to sitback and take your money.

I'm honestly finding it hard to explain this game, the only advice I can give is; if you've ever wanted to play the Game of Thrones this is the closest you'll ever get. In fact, do yourself the pleasure of visiting: http://citadel.prophpbb.com/forum3.html and checking out the amazing Game of Thrones mod these guys have been making over the last year or so (WARNING: May contain spoilers for TV viewers).

reviewText:
Crusader Kings II is a medieval politics grand strategy game. Maneuver nobility relations as you seek to expand the power and prestige of your dynasty, generations after generations.

Pros: Where to begin? There are countless characters (thousands): barons, counts, dukes, kings, courtiers, family members and everything in between for every city, barony, county, tribe, sheikdom or other political region denominator. Relationship behaviors are based off a multitude of character and personality traits. You manage a character, and upon death his heir, then his heir, through centuries of history as kingdoms and empires rise and fall, acquiring lordship over titles through conquering armies, political weddings, intrigue and backstabbing. The base game is set specifically for Europeans during the crusades, while expansions add Northern Africa, Middle East, Scandinavia, Western Asia and India, with each distinct culture and religion having its own tribal, feudal and monarchic mechanics. Many random events allow you to determine what type of person your current character becomes, engrossing you in the story of each of them, influencing and determining the fate of any trivial or world changing event. The game is regularly and constantly being updated: I'm not only referring to the multitude of DLCs that add historically accurate ethical portraits and cultural armory, but actual core mechanics are regularly revised, enhanced and added to by the developers. The game is fully open-ended, and leaves you to determine your political goal. Do you wish to rebuild the Roman Empire? Unite Great Britain? Overcome enemies in a world-wide crusade? Overthrow the Pope? Found Ukraine? Survive the Mongol onslaught? Endless possibilities!

Cons: The game has a high learning curve, and new comers must be willing to put in hours of learning, trial and error, and tutorial reading to understand how every mechanic works. Graphics are passable, barely enough to serve the game's purpose. Even at easier levels, difficulty remains high and players must be willing to go through constant frustrations as you are limited to decisions your character makes as a single person, which means there is no direct control over the outcome of battles, plots and events. The game can be slow at times, sometimes requiring months, years, decades and even generations of in-game time to bring any plan to fruition.

Verdict: ★★★★★ - Play this. Now.

This game isn't meant for everyone. It requires a lot of patience and dedication. But the game can also be immensely rewarding when you successfully achieve your goals. This game left me retelling the tales of how, as a count, I married my firstborn son to a duchess so that my grandson would inherit the king's throne (and expected to play that character two generations later), just to have my second son get branded as a kinslayer for killing his eldest brother, becoming my new heir and throw my entire plan to smithereens! The game is addictive, so if you have the patience to play through Cruisader Kings II's demo tutorial, you just have to get the entire game!

—————————————————————————
This was just my opinion.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

reviewText:
This game might be intimidating and you need a couple minutes/hours to watch various tutorials/lets play in youtube just to get some grasp on how to play the game. Dont launch this expecting a Sid Meier's Civilization type of game or you will be dissappointed.

But its worth it once you overcome that. The game is full of intrigue, backstabbing, incest and other things that you will do just to retain/expand your territory and continue your dynasty.

And also one more thing. Dont get complacent when everything is going your way as tragedy can strike in just a couple of turns.

reviewText:
The best (it's clear that Paradox own the genre, but this is their best one) Grand Strategy game. Whilst fans of strategy games may miss the interactive combat, this game makes up for it by being more interactive in other aspects such as diplomacy. Take your house and make it last throughout the ages! Who doesnt want to conquer the world?

It is one of the most complex games I have ever played and the learning curve is extremely steep, yet through playing the game it is easy to overcome (tutorials are provided, but they arent the most in depth).

The game has multiple DLC packs (which arent required, but they do make it more fun) and is being updated regularly.

Be prepared to become frustrated; I built my custom house (DLC) and it lasted throughout many centuries and when it came to  the 6 Generation, I was emperor of The Byzantine Empire, Britannia, Francia, The Holy Roman empire. The person I played, was infertile, and all other relatives had been killed off or were women (the game is against women, the populace hate you if youre a female ruler), my character died and with it my House. 100 hours I put in, to lose.
But remember, losing is fun!

9.8/10 losing the .2 for castration being available to only greeks.

reviewText:
Crusader Kings II is the sequel to the by now fairly old Crusader Kings and in true Paradox tradition it improves heavily upon every single aspect of the game. In particular the move to the Clausewitz engine needs a mention because it allows a game like Crusader Kings II to fully achieve it's potential in a way the previous game never could.

The game is a dynastic Grand Strategy game. This means that while you still take control of a single country like in other Paradox games are you not just some faceless entity behind the screens, you actually take control of that country's ruler and upon his or her death, take control of the legitimate heir to continue your reign. This makes controlling a country and leading it to greatness a much more personal experience as it's your family that's leading the charge, with the various offshoots that didn't manage to become King constantly plotting how to remove the current favorite.

In general much of the game will be spent dealing with your family and their thirst for power. Through a number of laws you can select who is the heir and how he or she is chosen and you can fully expect that anyone who doesn't not currently top that list will be working diligently to remove the one that does. And it's not always the best outcome when your able and strong son suffers an untimely accident and your gluttonous greedy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who is surprisingly proficient at intrigue becomes the last heir standing.

Like in most of Paradox's games warfare takes the front seat and it is the prime method for which to expand your lands, wealth and prestige. However Crusader Kings, through this dynastic system makes great strides towards making peacetime more interesting. The bigger your family, the more vassals you have, the more options will be available to you during peacetime and you will often have to work hard to keep your Kingdom stable. The option for marrying off unwanted sons to powerful widows is also a very effective way to increase your lands as you may one day some generations from now find yourself the heir to whole new territories. Quicker with a little creative assassination.

The graphics of the Clausewitz engine are beautiful although that is never really a necessity or a priority of a Grand Strategy game, particularly not a Paradox one, but it is nice to see that there's improvement on this front as well. The music is heavily mood setting and wonderful as always and the many small music DLC's available helps improve the selection tremendously.

All in all, Crusader Kings II does not disappoint as it proves itself a great sequel to a great game. Everything is simple better. A true must buy for any fans of Grand Strategy or Dynastic games. And for anyone that simply thinks incest is hilarious.

Also, completely irrelevant to the game, I'd strongly recommend that you go watch the Seven Deadly Sins" trailers on youtube that were released as promotional material before the game came out. They are definitely worth a watch whether you want to play the game or not."

reviewText:
I loved this game, but due to the battle changes and 'coalition/defensive pact' changes in conclave, as well as bugs that have persisted for over a year (The worst of which is when a revolt leader dies they'll just get their own independant country instead of folding back into yours), and repeated dlc thats weak on content I can no longer recommend it.

Paradox seems invested in their vision of nofun mechanics that don't make the game more challanging, just more tedious (shattared retreats, hosts, defensive pacts, as well as a thousand tiny things that have been in the game for forever like being unable to end a revolt when a province is occupied for an enemy when an ai can totally do that),

Steam says I have 700 hours in this game,  I'd played close to double that since I didn't play with steam open when I started, and the last 100 hours of so have been me desperatly trying to overlook all the problems that have been introduced combined with the problems that have always been there that I looked past because the rest of the game was solid.

I don't want crusader kings to be europa universalis, and I don't want to play a game that is STILL a buggy mess years after release.

column81: like the Elective system allows vassals to choose the heir but restricts the choice to members of the current holders dynasty.\n\nUltimogeniture – the default succession type for Ilkhanate
column82: the Golden Horde and the barony of Altenburg
column83:
in which the youngest child of the ruler inherits all the rulers titles upon their death.

Appointment - Used by Holy Orders feudal vassals called Commanders. All feudal titles are granted by the Grandmaster and revert back to him after the holder dies.

Papal Succession - Pope's succesion law where elected Cardinal's chose the next Pope among themselves. Only used by the Pope if the player owns the Sons of Abraham DLC.

King and Emperor-level characters also have a special set of available laws
column85: which simulate the power exerted by the monarch over his vassals. For example
column87: the monarch cannot revoke vassal's titles
column88: and they only provide levies to their liege if they hold him or her in high regard. In "absolute crown authority law"
column89: the vassals are entirely forbidden of waging war against each other and foreign enemies and must provide a sizable amount of levies.\n\nThat's a really really good game for about 1894172381274109487128409 hours of gameplay."

reviewText:
After 1800+ hours playing Crusader Kings II, the most recent DLC and free content expansion, Conclave, has forced me to withdraw my formerly enthusiastic approval.  CKII used to be one of the premiere Grand Strategy titles available.  Sadly, over the course of several expansion/DLC releases the game has lost its way, becoming increasingly tedious and straying far from the original wonderful gameplay.

The Conclave DLC and the accompanying free content patch was released completely unbalanced and apparently largely untested.  It caused a widespread negative reaction which forced Paradox to immediately begin work on a fix patch.  That patch, now in open beta testing, goes a long way toward fixing the worst of the problems.  Unfortunately, it doesn't go far enough.

The root of the problem is that the entire concept of Conclave makes councils far too powerful.  The intent of Paradox seems to be to make the game more difficult and thus hinder the ability of players to paint" the map all in the color of their empire.  The intended result was achieved.  And now the game is a mess of micromanaging council votes and council favor which detracts from the initial design concept of a fun game focused on dynasties and war in the medieval period.  Paradox might as well change the name of the game to Crusader Kings II: The Council -Hindered
date: Blocked and Trolled.  The game is no longer focused on dynasty and conquest and religious fervor in the medieval milieu.  Now it is just a grumpy
recommended: greedy pseudo-democracy council simulator set in a medieval era with the player forced into spending inordinate amounts of time dealing with fractious
hoursPlayed: constant council problems almost to the exclusion of everything that once made this a great game.\n\nCongratulations
voteText: Paradox.  The greed pushing a need to continually release more DLC to line corporate pockets has finally sent the core game into oblivion. You succeeded in satisfying a vocal minority who wanted the game to be more difficult (with no proof that many of those who complained had even played the game beyond the Easy setting).  In return
helpfulPercent: you've so drastically altered the basic gameplay that Crusader Kings II is no longer really about Crusader Kings.  You've turned a fine Grand Strategy game set in the medieval period into something entirely different. Short of removing the Conclave DLC and the free content expansion entirely
votesHelpful: there is no fix for this.  The game has moved too far from its original design concept
votesTotal: which attracted many of us to the game in the first place.  There are other better democracy simulators available.  They aren't Grand Strategy games; but neither is Crusader Kings II since the changes of the last expansion."

reviewText:
You know you’ve been playing too much Crusader Kings II when you start arranging betrothals between your and your friend’s children and spend the rest of your time musing on heraldry. Crusader Kings II is an ambitious strategy masterpiece full of intrigue, diplomacy, and war. The player controls a single noble dynasty through the European middle ages in a world as changeable as it is engaging.

One word I would definitely not use to describe Crusader Kings II is ‘accessible’. When I first started the game, I had to sort through dozens of menu screens and tabs trying to figure out to do. I can’t be sure, but at one point I think I accidentally attempted to abdicate the Duchy of Kent in favor of my Norwegian half-brother. There certainly were helpful messages and tips in great abundance, but if I really wanted to spend an hour reading, I would be downloading O. Henry short stories, not starting up a new game.

Once you do get the hang of the controls, though, Crusader Kings II opens up to almost endless possibilities. You can expand your dynasty by clever power play, strategic marriages, or through military force alone. If you work hard as an impoverished count, your grandchildren could be kings and queens. In a game revolving around diplomacy, however, the AI can be a little off-putting in its lack of complexity. While computer players are reasonably clever, they always make the most rational choice, which makes you feel a bit out of place as you attempt to coerce an Arabian sheikh to help you to invade Sweden.

The graphics are nothing to write home about, unless you wanted to let your folks know that games can be released in 2012 and still run on any computer more advanced than an abacus. The Crusader Kings II interface is basically a detailed map surrounded by different menus. If you weren’t wearing your glasses, it would look a lot like Total War, only you can’t zoom in for battles- all physical conflict is resolved off-screen as you watch the number of troops still alive decrease. The constant music definitely helps to distract from the less-than-interesting graphics. The same tracks are played over and over, but they’re epic enough to make it worth it.

The beautiful thing about Crusader Kings II is the way it generates stories through emergent gameplay. Take King Tudwal the Great, who loved gardening but would occasionally fly off the handle and kill his own family members, or Count Oberto, who despairingly turned to a scholarly life after failing to find a bride for his homosexual nephew. These aren’t characters you find in most Triple-A games.

If you only want to relax for a few minutes, you would probably be best served playing Plants vs Zombies, but if you want to spend a challenging 400 years taking over medieval Europe through vilest treachery, Crusader Kings II is without rival. Now if you’ll excuse me, my uncle just raised the banners of Scotland in rebellion against his Welsh overlords.

reviewText:
Crusader Kings 2 is probably the most reactionary game ever made. Imagine Game of Thrones without the fantasy stuff. This is a game about killing your kin to steal their lands, diplomatically marrying daughters off to sadistic freaks, crushing peasant revolts, and crusading against the Mohammadeans. Whether you chose to play as the Holy Roman Emperor or the count of a single back country province you’ll have plenty of court intrigue to keep you occupied. It is ½ grand strategy game, ½ dynastic RPG, and 100% awesome.

With the various DLCs you can play as non Christian religions too. I highly recommend picking up at least the Sword of Islam and Old Gods DLCs so you can play Muslims and Pagans respectively.

reviewText:
You know, I feel like ,compared to some of the great players (e.g. those mad tings' with 2000+ hours invested into the game) I really haven't experienced that much. In fact, I haven't even managed to run through a full game yet, that is both from the DLC-given 769 Charlemagne starting date and the vanilla 1066 date, and I like to consider myself a competent player - atleast I would hope so by this point... BUT, by my sweet black baby jesus' grace, it was when all of this hit me that I decided to write this review.

That is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing.

400+ hours of gameplay, nearing 500, and I still haven't managed to finish a game?

CK2 is the ultimate strategy out there. It doesn't recquire particularly acute battle-planning however, that is all done by a simple combat simulator and AI Martial Ability, no. This sort of strategy is that of court intrigue, seducing the Queen of Lombardy and marrying her so your heir becomes King of Italy whilst also coming from a family of barbaric Norse pagans?

What? The predominantly Catholic Italians don't like the idea of having a Pagan King and try revolt against you? Beat them down then, that's what your well groomed retinues are for.

But still your Council might find themselves growning a tad bit agitated with your ritual sacrifice of their fellow Christians and might attempt to, instead of overthrowing you competely, limit your power with diplomacy and the use of a strange concept. Democracy. Well, ♥♥♥♥ them, send your spymaster with his seditious intent to capture or kill them.

All this in the meagre period of twenty years.

Who knows what other trials, tribulations and resounding triumphs, await you upon your purchase of this game?
Well to answer that. No-one. Because the possibilities are, literally, absolutely infinite.

Oh and I also suggest shelling out, legit, everything in your wallet on the main DLCs, which are everything exluding Aztec Invasion.

reviewText:
This is a great medieval simulator. The combat aspects are extremely downplayed leaving you to focus on your court polotics and intrugue. You play as a medieval lord ranging from count to duke to king. You journey through time making plays for power within your kingdom you will advance through lines of succesion to the next generation.

Go on crusades to claim the holy land from infedels, and wage holy war against the pagan heathens, all the while staving off rebellion and rogue lords attempting to usurp your domain.

This game features rts sandbox and rpg aspects and it well worth the  sale price of $10 for the vanilla client. IMO the republic dlc, the old gods dlc, and legacy of rome are the most worthwhile and neccesary dlc. The rest mostly just come down to personal preferance and what you think you will play.

You can find plenty of mods on the paradox forum including a game of thrones westeros mod (the whole time i was playing vanilla i was wishing there was a game like that and when i found it on the forums i was ecstatic). The middle earth mod and tamriel mods are in development as of yet.

If you are unsure about buying this game give the demo a try or maybe check out some lets play videos on u tube. Overall this game is wonderful and deserves your attention if not only briefly to experience the greatness that is ck2.

reviewText:
Hello Gamers! PET here with my Crusader Kings II review!

First of all this is a hard game to pick up but once you do it will create one of the best and unique experiences you ever encounter (in video games lol).

If you follow my video at the end of the review I guarantee you will be able to pick up the game. If not...

CK2 is a Grand Strategy Game. You will start around year 1100 and play until around 1300 (don't remember the exact dates. You can change the start year but the end year will be the same).

CK2 is a game about your dynasty, about politics, about your vassals and about surviving your dynasty. One of the reasons why this game is hard is that it does not give you a purpose. You can do whatever you want and this might be confusing to some people. You will get that now what?" experience. Not only that but you will be able to play with any king/duke/count in Europe. As you see I wrote a person title and not a country. Why? Because in CK2 you play with a person from a dynasty. Your purpose is to expand your dynasty
date: marry your sons so they can create children
recommended: marry your daughters to other powerful rulers so you will have a claim on that territory... oh yes yes...\n\nCK2 follows the feudal system and that's one of the reasons why people find this game hard. For example you can not declare war on another person without having a De Jure claim. What does that mean? Well it means that you are entitle to that territory because you might have a title that contains that territory. Oh yes

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EYoByvot6K0

But trust me guys

Be that you want to drown your incapable rival in the bath, or throw your own mum off the castle balcony with a wooden horse, you can do it, provided you don't get excommunicated in the process.

reviewText:
500 hours. Five. Hundred. Hours.
Since I purcahased Crusadser Kings II for $23.99 on July 17, 2012, roughly %3.5 of my life has been devoted solely to this game.
And I'm still playing.
Why? Because it's a masterpiece. I can comfortably say this is the overall best game I have ever played. Maybe I'm a history nerd, maybe I like maps, maybe I enjoy imprisioning and killing all my relatives so that little genius baby boy can have a shot at becoming the first Breton to rule all of Western Europe. Could be there's something cathartic about converting to Cathar just so you can launch a holy war against the Pope who gave you all your power with that invasion CB against the HRE in the first place. Maybe it's the strategy, so deep that I still find myself looking to the wiki to find the most efficient way to conquer. I might get a little too into the roleplaying, would my kind, charitable, humble, Catholic duke really execute his own son just because he's a drunken imbecile? I know I'm not entirely sure what keeps bringing me back, but I do know that the sheer replayability of this game is staggering. If you're thinking about buying this game, seriously consider whether you have any real work you'd like to get done in the next two years, because more than likely you're going to be plotting against your liege rather than plotting out your next project at the office, or whatever...

reviewText:
A complex game to get into, however a fantastic piece of strategy gameplay focusing on the people that run the areas, and the political intrigue and interactions. Where political machinations and plots are more important than raw military might.

The DLC expansions are also excellent adding even more events and ways to play. I've personally played as the Irish, and the Norse ancestry Scots in the Old Gods expansion, and the game changes considerably between the cultures, which is interesting.

And of course there is the Game of Thrones mod, which is just icing on the cake.

reviewText: This is my most played game. What can I say?  I just killed 2 of my grandson's and my son, so that my second eldest son would inherit the thrones of Absynnia and Nubia.  My selected heir has taken the throne and I've decided to try and declare a holy war against my Sunni neighbors to the north who are involved in a huge civil war.  A big mistake, I've miscalculated.  My levies, along with my Vassal's and a regiment of mercenaries are overun by superior numbers as we tried to siege their stronghold.  We're forced to retreat. I sue for a white peace.  Luckily, thier own civil war pushes them to accept.  It is costly, my prestige takes a hit with the added insult of losing half my coffers in the treaty.  My armies now lay in tatters.  Time to lick my wounds and take lesson from my hastily planned attack. Next time I will be properly prepared.  Next time, victory will be mine.

reviewText: This is grand strategy on an epic scale with a steep learning curve.  It has been a lot of fun and very challenging.  I can see myself putting in a ton of hours.  Don't get discouraged by the complex mechanics because once you learn a little, you will probably be hooked, like me.  It's all about creating a dynasty, breeding strong leaders, marrying into power, and conquering kingdoms and empires.  I have found my favorite strategy game of the decade.
