reviewText:
SummaryAn amazingly complex and engrossing game that can make the hours fly by.

ReviewCrusader Kings II is difficult to classify. It’s a grand strategy game, a sandbox game, and in some ways a political simulator. It also happens to be one of the best role-playing games I've ever played.  I’m not even sure where to begin describing it, but what I can say without reservation is that it’s extremely immersive and fun, which is quite a trick that developer Paradox Interactive pulled off when you consider that the vast majority of the gameplay takes place in menus.

The premise is deceptively simple: you play as a king (hardly a surprise given the game's title), and your number one goal above all else is to have an heir in place who will claim your throne upon your death.  When your character dies, you assume the role of his heir, and so on down the line of succession.  Die without an heir and it's game over.

But of course it’s not quite as simple as that.  As a king, you’re naturally going to want to expand your realm and accumulate wealth and prestige, and this is where you find the meat of the game.  When you start, you can choose to play as anything from a lowly vassal like a duke or a petty king ruling a single province to a monarch of an entire country.  This also serves as a secondary way to adjust the game’s difficulty since a duke or petty king is going to have a harder time of it than the ruler of an entire nation.

And this is where things get interesting.  I call Crusader Kings II a role-playing game because it’s all about navigating the treacherous path of court intrigue and maintaining relationships with the other characters in the game.  Sometimes you might want to have a good relationship with someone, or sometimes you may want them to think very poorly of you, and there are numerous means for doing both, from performing favors, or handing out honorary titles (including Court Jester, which never makes the recipient happy), or even straight-up bribery.  If you have a troublesome vassal, you can try and woo him back into your good graces, throw him in jail, or plot to have him killed.  Any action you choose will always have long-term consequences, for good or ill.  For instance, if you arbitrarily throw someone in jail, or attempt to have them murdered and it’s discovered, you’ll take a relationship hit with other characters almost across the board, and this could be a problem if allies refuse to come to your aid during war, or you end up with a revolt on your hands, or other characters hatch their own plans to kill you or your heir!  It all becomes a delicate balancing act as you try to keep your friends (and enemies) happy while scheming to steal land and titles out from under their noses.

In addition to good old fashioned political intrigue, you will also encounter a number of random story vignettes that present your character with various choices that create a short, branching narrative, the ultimate consequences of which could be positive or negative, depending on your decisions.

When things come to blows, and they inevitably will, it’s time to raise an army and clash steel.  Unfortunately, this is not the most engrossing part of the game.  Your armies march around in multi-unit “blobs” represented by a single soldier sprite with a number indicating the size of the army and a small line representing its morale.  Essentially, if your numbers are higher than an enemy army’s numbers then you’ll (most likely) win the battle.  And that’s pretty much all there is to it: march your “blob” around, defeat other blobs, and lay siege to enemy provinces until your war score reaches 100% and you can force your foe to concede to your demands.  I’m not saying this is necessarily easy, and wars are extremely costly, and sometimes you’ll be thrown an unexpected wrinkle that will turn what you thought was an easy victory into a crushing defeat, but you’re not going to find detailed tactical gameplay here (although full disclosure compels me to mention that I’m not an expert in this game by any stretch, so there may be some nuance here that I’m missing).  At any rate, the simple combat mechanics are adequate because war really isn’t the focus of Crusader Kings II even if it is an important aspect given the setting.

Crusader Kings II plays in real-time, but you can pause at any point if you need breathing room to untangle a particularly difficult political conflict.  You can still interact with the game when it’s paused, but your orders won’t take affect until you start the clock again.  This prevents the game from becoming overwhelming even when things get complicated, which can happen very quickly and often without warning.  Thankfully the interface is very well laid out and places the copious amounts of information you need to manage your empire within easy reach, usually no more than one or two mouse-clicks away.  However, it is a very complex game, and even with over 80-hours under my belt to date, I feel like I’ve still barely scratched the surface.  In order to understand Crusader Kings II, you need to have a basic understanding of Medieval politics and laws, and this isn’t something that most people possess.  For instance, a pop-up will inform you that you have a “Wrong type of holding in demesne”.  What does that even mean, and more importantly, how do you fix it?  Or you might discover that your kingdom is at risk of fragmenting into the hands of multiple petty rulers when your character dies because of a potential succession crisis.  Why is this happening, and what can you do about it?  The game’s manual and tutorial missions do a rather poor job preparing you for your career as a crusader king, so you’ll probably want to find some “Let’s play” videos or a strategy guide or two.  I also suggest keeping a web browser handy while you play because you’ll inevitably have questions throughout the course of the game.

Graphically, Crusader Kings II is probably about as attractive as a game like this can be with the majority of the display occupied by a vast interactive 3D map.  Details are added and subtracted depending on your zoom level, so it’s easy to pull out for a quick overview and then zoom in close enough to see individual cities and holdings dotted across the landscape.  It also runs beautifully in Linux, which always scores extra points in my book.  Sound effects are pretty basic for the most part, but you’ll mostly be listening to the music anyway which is period appropriate orchestral selections.  It can get a little bit repetitive, but there are several music packs available as DLC to expand the score.

Speaking of DLC, if you’re contemplating a purchase of Crusader Kings II, you might be staggered by the fact that there is, at the time of this writing, nearly $250 worth of full-priced DLC currently available, and you may find this off-putting, but consider this: the vanilla game offers a complete experience in and of itself and can give you hours of entertainment.  In fact, I would recommend you play it sans DLC at first to get a feel for the game and to decide which DLC actually appeals to you, because not all of it will (and you should probably wait until it’s on sale anyway to get the most bang for your bucks).  I personally only have around half of the available DLC including several expansions and some of the unit and music packs, but I don’t feel like I’m missing out simply because the other content doesn’t interest me.  I should also note that when Paradox does release a major expansion, it's always accompanied by a patch that adds new features and content to the base game for free.

This review could easily be three times as long, and I still wouldn’t feel like I had given a comprehensive description of Crusader Kings II.  So let’s make this simple: It’s a great game.  Buy it.

reviewText:
Grand strategy game (real time with pause) taken to a very personal level: rather than making sure your country prospers, you are the head of a dynasty and growing prestige of your dynasty is your main interest.

Being a ruler of a prospering country certainly helps with growing prestige, but at the end of the day your dynasty must prevail, not this or that country... When you die, you take up the mantle as your heir - and really the only way to lose is not to have a heir at all, never mind the possible ruin you put your kingdom (duchy? county? empire?) in.

Feel like assassinating your old, barren wife yet? Or at least making some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s to legitimize on the side?

Have you seen the cinematic  on the store page? Go see it. If you think they're joking - nope, stuff like that can really happen. Every bit of it. And more. Much more. Real game of thrones  material here. You can build an army and conquer, but dividing with intrigue and tactical assassination is also a big thing.

Emergent gameplay in a true strategy at its finest. The stories you can tell after you're done with your playthrough? Priceless.

There may be quite a bit to take on at first learning-curve-wise but it *so* much worth it.

reviewText:
To be honest, I love this game for several reasons.

1) I'm a huge fan of strategy and history.

2) The game is several years old, but still receives updates and DLC.

3) Well-made and high quality.

4) Easy to get immersed and endless replayability with hundreds of characters/dynaties to choose from. And of course, you have the whole insane Game of Thrones style politics, backstabbing, intrigue, etc.

5) Learning curve is a bit steep like many grand strategy games, but very rewarding once mastered.

reviewText:
I have played this game for over 400 hours. Expanded my Empire from one small Baltic tribe. Expanded real Baltic religion to nearly all north Europe. Then - wham! New patch! Patch which broke all game system. Technology points were all gone, vassal opinions were all gone or of some enourmous amounts. Prestige points, piety points, score points, all gone or of enourmous amounts too. Contacted Paradox, asked for help - got replay that game system changed becouse of the latest patch.

Okey I thought to my self, scew these 400 hours or carefull planning and conquest. I will start anew, better Baltic Empire. Not to mention the pain with Viking leaders/founders of Kiev rus and Novgorod, which are imba, packed with stats like on uber steroids, but they also get a huge packs of army right from the start. So I had to defend from them. Plan my battle carefully. Picking a place and time. I beat them in first battle and made them retreat and then - wham! New mechanic - Shattered Retreat".

"Shattered Retreat"
So that imba unber steroid packed doom ball just retreated and I had to chase them all the way to their lands. Till I got to them
date: they have already recovered in morale and received reinforcements. I nearly lost that other battle. And it happened again - they just made Shattered Retreat again! And again I had to run around threw all the map just to get into same doom ball with full morale and reinforcements! But by that time my vassals were mad at me because I took their armies for too long and my gold account was empty.\n\nI have bought nearly all DLCs for this game. It's roughtly 250 EUROs and I get this
recommended: Paradox?!\nSo this is what you developed all this time using your player community money
hoursPlayed:
Paradox?!

I am stating very clearly for the new commers - DONT BUY THIS GAME !!! You will be scewed up time after time and after time.

Shattered Retreat mechanic was a last nail into the coffin that I am putting this game into

Paradox. You failed miserable... just pathetic.

reviewText: Crusader Kings II is by far the most detailed dynastic sim (and only decent one) I've had the pleasure of playing. Imagine becoming any landed nobleman from the past and rewriting your family- and the world's, history. Any strategy gamer or enthusiast should look to this title if they want a level of depth and detail beyond anything else out in the market. Better yet, finish a play through and then load your save game file onto Europa Universalis 4 and watch your empire through the next era of history!

reviewText:
For the first two weeks of playing Crusader Kings 2 I sucked so bad at managing my dynasty that game sessions usually lasted for about an hour or so before they descended into chaos, civil wars and invasions, which inevitably lead to the complete annihilation of the great house of Insertnamehere and its disappearance from the pages of history.

And I didn't even mind.

Even when you fail at CS2, you fail so spectacularly and so interestingly that you can't help but enjoy yourself. Mayhap a long lost cousin emerged with an army and an ultimatum, seizing the throne and throwing you from high king to lowly duke? Mayhap that lovingly concocted poisonous wine you gave your spouse for you anniversary finally kicked in, but you were discovered and now his or her lover plots revenge? Or mayhap you managed to unite the Holy Roman Empire and Byzantium, ushering in an era of peace and prosperity under the watchful eye of a united Rome, only to have the Golden Horde drop by for tea and biscuits?

Whatever happens you'll greet it with a grin 'cause, damn it, you won't be able to help yourself.

reviewText: Crusader Kings II is not Civilization. And, unlike other Paradox games such as the Europa Universalis series, it is not hard to learn. You play as a ruler, of a county, a duchy, a kingdom, or an empire. You choose initially from the set of rulers available at the start of the game, which is by default anyone in power in 1066 CE Europe (Further back with the Old Gods expansion) and from then on, things get rough. If your ruler dies, you then play as your immediate heir. If you have no heir, then you lose the game, so the simplest goal would be to have your dynasty survive the lenght of the game (some 400 years). Only there's so much more to do than survive. You have to plan marriages for your daughters and sons, deal with an often angry Pope, vicious neighbors with claims on your lands, angry subordinates who may be plotting to kill you or usurp your titles, a derelict king or queen who thinks they're posessed by the devil and are putting the kingdom you belong to on the fast track to destruction, an angry horde of mongols rapidly advancing, a holy war tearing apart a nearby kingdom, and so much more. It doesn't take long to get immediately caught up in the scheming and politics of even the tiniest duchy, and before you know it two hundred years have passed, kingdoms have risen and fallen, assassins have come and gone, plagues have ruined your best laid plans for succession, and you realize it's eight AM and you've been caught up in medieval rulership for all night.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

Better yet, finish a play through and then load your save game file onto Europa Universalis 4 and watch your empire through the next era of history!

reviewText:
TL;DR: 9.9/10 (nearly perfect).
Pros: too many to quickly list, see paragraph below.
Cons: steep learning curve, and potential expense of the full (& extremely important) game in the form of tons of DLC.

CK2 has quickly become one of my favourite games of all time. This game is such a fun mix of history/alternate history, intrigue, state/empire building, and ruler simulator. The possibilities available (with all the DLC) are so numerous that during the 400+ hours I’ve played I’ve barely scratched the surface. Wonder what would happen if the Vikings had conquered, held, and integrated Italy into the Swedish or Norwegian kingdoms? DO IT. Getting tired of the Catholics attacking you when you play as the Umayyads (muslim rulers of the Iberian peninsula)? Holy war all the Catholic countries, take their territory and convert their populations to Islam; Rome the center of Catholicism? Not any more! take it from the Infidels and make it Sunni (or Shi'a), or if you're not muslim then convert it to Norse or any of the multitude of diverse and historically accurate religions .  The possibilities for epic, world" conquering and non-historically accurate shenanigans are nearly infinite.  Let your inner history nerd free
date: and mess with the world in a fun
hoursPlayed: and often very personal way. Another important aspect of this game besides the world conquering/state building is the character aspect.  Instead of just playing a country you are actually an individual (a count
voteText: duke
helpfulPercent: king
votesHelpful: or emperor).  Individuals have traits which affect (positively or negatively) their stats which in turn affect the functionality of your state.  There are thousands of unique events for your character to “interact” with
votesTotal: adding an aspect of role playing that is not merely a side thing but a full fledged and fleshed out mechanic.  All the possibilities and outcomes an individual character can experience keeps the game from being just another conquer the enemies territory and “take over the world” (brain) game and elevates it into a unique class of it’s own. There are only two negatives to this game
votesFunny: both of which ultimately don’t affect it's enjoyability. First problem is the price of the game and all it’s DLC. To get the best (and “real”) CK2 experience you really do need all the DLC and when it’s not on sale this game can cost $150+. Lucky the game goes on sale frequently and I’ve been able to (over some time) acquire all the DLC for much
commentsCount: MUCH less than $150. I don’t know exactly how much but it’s probably only like $40/50. Buying the "complete package" at the start when on sale costs $40 and is definitly a perfect deal.  Le'ts just say that despite not paying $150+ for the game I've definitly gotten WAY more than $150 worth of fun from it. I'm glad I didn't pay that much but now that I know how good the game is and if I had to go back & pay the full price I wouldn't hesitate.  The second problem is the learning curve. Being a grand strategy game there is a MASSIVE amount of stuff to learn.  I’m not the sharpest tool in the shed so it took me a good 50+ hours before I was confident enough to say I fully knew how to play.  The 50ish hours I spent learning were fun but I didn’t realize how amazing this game is until I actually got fluent in the game (around 100+ hours in).  Now though that i’ve “mastered” how the game is played I struggle to name a game I’ve enjoyed playing more (ok I know: The Binding of Isaac/Rebirth).  One way to help speed up learning the ins & outs is to watch tutorial/let’s play videos. There is a youtuber named Arumba who is not only extremely entertaining but is also a CK2 master.  Watching his CK2 content really helped accelerate my enjoyment and understanding of the game. I fully recommend watching some tutorial/let’s play videos while/before playing the game

reviewText:
Easily one of the most entertaining games Ive ever owned. I picked this game up for 10 dollars on sale, and for the first time ever I feel like I owe the company more money for what they provided me!

Disclaimer: This game has the absolute steepest learning curve Ive ever overcome. The tutorials are pretty useless, some are broken, and dont explain features too well. Most everyone learns how to paly by watching youtube videos, of which there are many excellent series.

Disclaimer Disclaimer: This is not for those who enjoy fastpaced gameplay. It is not like the Total War franchise where you take command of your armies. The entire game is played out on the map.

That all being said with a little patience and little imagination this game offers literally endless fun. So many different ways to play, every single game will be different. And if any of you people out there are familiar with the phrase Its fun to loose!"
date: then this is for you.\n\nYoull get so many cool stories to tell
recommended: and the community is nothing short of wonderful. Everyone is helpful and polite (for the most part
hoursPlayed: much better than most other communities). Highly

reviewText: Deep and powerful trip into Western feudalism, not only as a historical period, but as a mindset. Should be brought into history classes to make people understand this way of thinking, which is not as medieval as one might assume. Wrapping your mind around it is highly rewarding, provided you don't mind somewhat steep learning curve, are creative enough to set up your own goals, and you like to see  all your plans screwed in alternative history turmoils. And of course provided that you find it amusing to see your life being sucked by his monster...

reviewText:
This game is only worth it if you've played other strategy games and gotten bored because there isn't enough detail.
You can plot to kill a member of your court, join a war, start a war, arrange marriages, imprison people, execute those people and quell some rebellious villagers while you're at it.

In my game I helped my uncle take over Norway and once he had won using his wealth and considerable armies I had him assassinated and inherited it all at almost no cost to myself. Felt very game of thrones-esque.

The one thing to be warned of is that since I bought this game a couple years ago the developer has removed things from the game and resold them as DLC, they've also added a bunch with DLC and continue to do so but my advice is to be careful with your money because you can easily overspend on this game to have a more complete" experience.

*EDIT* I should add that this game is very poorly optimized so even though it's a very fancy 2D game you can easily encounter very significant FPS problems given that the game seems to only utilize one CPU core. It starts off strong but the longer the game the more Ai characters your computer has to manage and that slows it down considerably."

reviewText: Incredibly addictive. The depth and the range of options are very impressive. Sometimes it feels a bit odd with the strict rules of family management (like, why can't I as an Emperor persuade my lackwit elder son that he's better off in a monastery than ruling; had to excommunicate him and then reconciled and sent him to monastery nevertheless).\nAllows some really strange manipulations with history. I rebuilt the Roman Empire through heroic attempts of three consecutive female Empresses and finally a couple of decent male rulers. And that's a pretty tame story if you compare to what people are posting here and elsewhere.\nAbsolutely worth playing a lot.

reviewText:
Let me describe how my first Crusader Kings 2 game began and you'll hopefully appreciate the fun that this game can offer:

my character was over 60 year old Duke of southern Ireland. I had two sons, eldest of which was to be my successor, but who had such personality quirks that I really didn't think he would be the right heir. I preferred the younger son. So I sent the eldest on the most dangerous assignment I could - collecting taxes and hoped for the best (or worst). At the same time I noticed that I had good relations with France and the king of France happened to have two daughters (princesses) in the ripe age for marriage. I tested my luck and offered to wed the other and my eldest son could wed the other. Luckily the king accepted my proposals and there I was, married to a french princess.

Not long after the marriage I decided to start fooling around with the other princess as well, because you can't go wrong with two french princesses and as my son was all the time fetching taxes, you had to give some warmth to the lonely french woman in another country.

Not long after I got good (bad) news that my son had been killed on his taxation trip and I managed to get the right son to be my lawful heir. I kept the princesses though to myself naturally. At this point I noticed that the french king had an heir, son of age 8 or so. This wouldn't do because I wanted to get France for me as well so I put some plans into work and decided to assassinate the brat. I went a bit over the top though because I invested so much money into the assassination that it had approximately 300% success rate and indeed, after a while I got notice that he was at the same time thrown from the balcony, put into fire and shot with a crossbow. But if you want to get rid of a french king-to-be you better make it right the first time, can't be too careful!
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Grab Civ 5, Mount & Blade: Warband and the Sims series and you get this game. So far it beats every strategy name I ever laid my hands on and I only have 200 hours in it as of yet.
The learning curve is long and painstaking, but it's definitely worth it.

Many people complain about the immerse amount of DLC's that should be included in the vanilla, but once you grind your teeth and decide to buy some of them, (besides they are on sale rather frequently) you won't regret it as each one of them give something to the game that you otherwise would have missed. For instance (dlc's I have so far):

- Legacy of Rome: Retinues and the Byzantine Empire
- The Old Gods: the struggles of tribal people, conquering your way to feudalism/republics, also, raid europe to pieces
- The Republic: start out slow and have huge armies, even as a single county ruler... or even just as a patrician vassal
- Horse Lords: it's bloody hard, still just learning, but the hordes you can recruit are amazing
- Charlemagne: another +100 years of (IRL) gameplay + tons of new tribal characters
- Sword of Islam: another take on feudalism, plus roughly 1/3 of the map unlocked to play with
- Way of Life: all the character focuses and the events they generate give the game so much more... the Seduction focus seems to be hated by the community, but it's fun, especially when you play with your friends. :P Also, don't be surprised if you die of syphilis.
- Sons of Abraham: Jewish characters unlocked and some extra gold to be borrowed in times of need
- Conclave: Your own council becomes your worst enemy, imo makes the game slightly harder

All in all, a great game, the only thing I could see it being better is if Paradox made multiplayer more stable, my friends often complain they've lost control over their troops and the game client needs rebooting, also whenever someone drops from the host, everyone has to reboot the client, as the multiplayer button is greyed out. Now this wouldn't bother me much, except sometimes you have to do it multiple times in a row until everyone can play again.
So for me, single player 9/10, it's almost flawless, but for multiplayer it's only an 8/10, still a great experience (the other day we were laughing our ♥♥♥♥ off on a lunatic character's horse councillor, then I murdered it), but some fixes need to be done to make it perfect.

I'd definitely recommend if:
- you like sandbox strategy games
- you like history and want to be part of it
- you'd like to know more about medieval hierarchy
- you'd rather lead a dynasty rather than a nation
- you just want to watch the world burn

reviewText:
By far, one of the best games I've played in my life

In Paradox's game progression this one is the first, and it occupies middle ages from 1066 to 1452 (or from 867 if you get the DLC for it). In game you basically have to choose dynasty and play till you die or till the game itself ends. And it's really ♥♥♥♥ing difficult. You might get kicked out of your throne and die poor with no heirs or you can survive and be emperor of whole Europe.

This game is great fun because:
1) It is really hardcore
2) The map is quite big, so variety of dynasties to play is really decent
3) Things go quite different every time you play, so it doesn't become repetitive
4) There are some quite competitive achievements in game, for example restoring Roman Empire or sample
5) It is quite historically interesting, you can watch how things changed around 1000 years ago
6) Nice graphically made landscape
7) It's not just about having wars. It's about being a ruler. You will have to do a lot of things there, from starting and ending wars to marrying your offsprings

Why this game isn't flawless:
1) Some really stupid and unrealistic things might happen. For example, Russian kingdom turning to catholic religion or black-skinned king of Britain (This is what I had only, most noticeable things)
2) There are really many DLCs and getting them can sometimes be worthy, the most significant ones are like 8$
3) Some DLCs are really stupid, for example the one with Aztec invasion. It's just plain idiotic.
4) This game might be sometimes TOO hardcore. You won't be able to play it normally before you complete tutorial, so bother yourself with that. And it's gonna take you a lot of time to start playing good. I actually started becoming good at this game after 100h only and still would sometimes get ♥♥♥♥ed.

Overall, this game is a great fun if you want some good time-spender, if you want some historical interesting events, if you're tired of real-time strategy games or if you just crave some difficult gameplay and not-so-stupid games. This is what you have to get then.

9.8/10, would play again and again

reviewText: This game was awesome. Key word 'was.' Poured a lot of time and effort into my Empire only to have an update absolutely ruin the ability to play any further. Apparently updates to this game have been doing this for awhile (making previous saves unplayable) the community would have you believe that plenty of warning is given on the forums. Whilst this may be true, purchase/playing of the game is in no way a binding agreement that a player must stay active on the forums and actively be a part of the community. Something you'll need to be (apparently) unless you don't want to be pre-warned about getting your save-games dicked. Of course there is plenty of warning about the available DLC in-game, but that takes precedence over anything else I guess... Great game, terrible update model. Extremely upset. Removed from my heart and /common file. :(\n\nEDIT: I gave the game a second chance and progressed well until receiving a sudden and inexplicable error message forced that game to a close too. I could not find any information online about what was happening so I signed up to the Paradox forums themselves and left a post in the relevant location asking for tech support. It has been viewed but gone unreplied to for the past two days. I guess you're scrwed whether you join the forums or not. In conclusion: don't purchase the game and don't support the developers. All in all a very frustrating experience playing (?) and dealing with their half-♥♥♥♥♥ performance in the gaming industry. Not good enough.

reviewText:
While Crusader Kings II is a good game in overall and by itself, it was severely screwed up since the release of the last DLCs.

Note that the major DLCs are not the problem, but the patches that came along with them. Since Rajas of India, the game went downhill.
While I can run the game normally (not as before, but still), some people that once could, cannot run as they used to due lack of optimisation.
Another problem Paradox have with their DLCs is that they do not acknowledge, or even accept failures even when most of the players are against the features. While the game has been patched up to deal with bugs and problems the last major patch has brought, they still maintain their decision not to take away things that were and are not well-welcomed since the beginning, even before releasing.
The last patch(which came with Conclave) brought with it Coalition and Shattered Retreat, features known to EUIV players and many CKII players were against them and just some liked (not counting the fanboys every game company has).
* Coalition was something that could be considered a joke - a system that when you grow, even against those against your faith (ie, Christian expanding over Muslims), can bring every realm, including those similar to you against you. It has been patched, but it's still rubbish. So if you are Jerusalem and expand over the Fatimids, expect Rome to go against you.
* Shattered Retreat was a bit more welcomed but it still doesn't make a lot of sense and was considered broken.

There are many more problems from patches from other DLCs, but as since I don't play much since Rajas and when I do, it's just with mods, I'm not really aware of them. But yet, Paradox seemingly does nothing to -really- deal with them.
In the past I could recommend this game, and would say it's one of the best I've ever played, but at the moment it's not really pleasant without mods. The way the game is today, I can say I have more fun playing CKI than playing CKII.

If you have never played CKII before or a game like it, you might enjoy as you won't see the difference from what it was at the beginning, but know that when it was released, or at the time of Old Gods, it was a much better game than what it is now and that is really a shame. CK2 is reaching its end, but if you're new to Paradox, be careful with your next deals as they might be just the same, now more than never.
I won't be buying anything from them any longer, at least until they stop doing what they are doing not only to CK2, but to EUIV, hence I expect the same from the new titles, such as HOIIV.

reviewText:
A game like no other. Yes, it is mostly watching the map and sometimes giving orders (which means clicking 2 or 3 buttons). But if you want a medival simulation as realistic as possible, then this is the game for you. Just do not expect a lot of action going on. Also do not expect a real-time or turn-based strategy game. This game is not about conquering the world (Europa Universalis IV might be more your game then...), it is about simulating the feudal system. Therefore, there are mechanisms in the game, such as inefficient taxation when you own too many provinces or the gavelkind succession laws that splits your realm between your children when you die. While these might look like huge fun-blockers for an average gamer, they perfectly make sense in this game. Again, this is a feudal simulation and it excels at this.

Recommended DLCs: The Old Gods, Sons of Abraham, Sword of Islam, Legacy of Rome.

For long-term playability: there is a huge amount of mods, including some total conversion mods that put you in the world of Middle-Earth (Lord of the Rings) or Westeros (Song of Ice and Fire" aka "Game of Thrones")."

reviewText:
Crusader Kings II: The latest entry in the Paradox Grand Strategy game lineup.

Unlike in most of Paradox's strategy games, you take control not of an entire nation, but of the rulers within that nation. If your ruler has no heir, it's game over. Duke, King, and Emperor are all well represented here. The base game starts in a pretty historical 1066 (the Old Gods expansion pushes it back to 876). However, once you unpause it, history is thrown out the window. Everything can change from there on out.

Once you are familar with the UI and pretty much all the features of it, which can take a while as Paradox's tutorial is not extremely helpful in that regard, you are ready to start a real campaign. You set the campaign goals, forma  specific empire or Dutchy, make your dynasty last to the end of the game, 1453. It's up to YOU.

Controling the leader is a nice change of pace as well, becaus eit adds an RPG like mechanic to a strategy game. Many things can happen to your character, and ultimatly death, and then you take control of his/her heir. The mechanics are fleshed out and deep. They feel meaningful. You need to have a reason to declare war, and a good portion of the time you only have claims to one province at a time. This makes conquest difficult, but rewarding a little more realistic than other Paradox games.

The graphics are pretty good for a strategy game of this nature, where you are essentailly staring at a map waiting for things to change. The Clauswitz engien does well in that regard. All the artwork ingame is beautifully done and looks marvelous.

In the end, the only thing that truly bugs me is the amount of DLC. Many of it is purly cosmetic and is not needed to fully enjoy the game, but they do add to the atmostphere. If you are to get any of the DLC make sure to get Sword of Islam, The Republic. The Old Gods, and The Legacy of Rome as those are the meaty expansion type DLC's. If you want a very ahistorical scenario pick up The Sunest Invasion" to have the Aztecs bid for control of Europe as well in an alternate history scenario.

Overall I give Crusader Kings II a 9/10."
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've never found a strategy game better than Crusader Kings II. I've owned it for nearly two years (ignore my playing hours, I actually have two copies of CK II; one from gamersgate, and one on Steam I picked up off the humble bundle), and I LOVE it. It's stunning in depth and complex like few other games, yet I found it easy to pick up and learn. Anyone who likes royalty, strategy, or family politics will love this game.

Graphics are great; beautiful even. Very few strategy games I've played have such beautiful graphics in every area - character portraits, interface art, maps - normally something out of those lets you down. To mention it comes with its own, original music - beautiful, fitting classical pieces.

I've found it to have infinite replay-ability. Not only because there are so many different characters you can try out (nearly anyone in mainland europe, and with DLCs all of India and the middle east), but because it has a great AI that always makes the world different each time. In the footsteps of real medieval europe, inheritance can change the map fundamentally. Play historically and rebuild the empires of a dynasty, or just conquer a whim - both are fun.

This game is also constantly updated. Paradox has a great DLC policy where you get nearly every bit of content without the DLC just in the updates - all the DLCs do are to make characters playable, introduce new starts and new interface themes. So if you don't want to pay, you don't have to; you still get most of the experience, and you won't be left behind if you want to play multiplayer with others. There is no DLC wall. Not to mention DLCs can be easily turned on and off via the launcher.

So much content has been added since I began playing, and the game is always getting better - just recently they doubled the map size, an enormous amount of work for Paradox, nearly 2 year after the game came out.

My ratings?
Music - 9/10
Graphics - 8/10. Only thing that could be improved is player portraits might be higher-res.
Gameplay - 10/10
Replayability - 10/10
Updates - 10/10
Support - 9/10

Overall - 9/10.

reviewText:
A grand-strategy from the masters of the genre Paradox Development Studio. The game will feel familiar to those that have played other games from the developer, Europa Universalis etc, yet will be refreshing and worthwhile because of its focus on intrigue and dynasties rather than trade and nation level politics.

Crusader Kings II is one of the best, if not the best, grand-strategy game of recent years. The game offers hundreds of hours of gameplay (especially if you have the expansions) because of the vastly different experiences the various religions, cultures and ranks of nobility offer. The RPG elements and focus on your personal dynasty add another layer of depth with the micromanagement of every marriage, alliance and well placed dagger in the unfortunate cousin's back. The game is full of events from restoring the Roman Empire to building a flying machine, which add a lot of flavour and keep the playthroughs interesting and amusing.

The game also has a very good modding community, with mods ranging from the small ones that bring alternate flags and portraits to the total conversion mods such as:

'A song of Ice and Fire' mod:  Game of Thrones [forum.paradoxplaza.com]
'Elder Scrolls' mod:  Elder Kings [forum.paradoxplaza.com]

The mods, especially the total conversions, add a lot of value to the game.

The game is not beginner friendly, not by a long shot. Despite being more simple than other games in the genre the information overload will be a lot, especially for new players. If you're willing to take the time to learn the game, it will be an amazing experience.  I recommend the game to anyone who's interested Game of Thrones-esque intrigue.

reviewText:
This is a sandbox game where you given direct control of a single individual with the goal of preserving your family legacy. Gameplay is strategic and chaotic. It's one of the most fun things I've done in quite some time and I did start to really get into my character and their families.

For example,  One of the Nordic Kings sieged my castle in Dorset while my army was away helping an allied king, imprisoned my pregnant wife and then after she gave birth to my first son (while I had Agnatic Primogeniture Succession laws), held HIM hostage, took my wife as his concubine - and then continued to siege my lands.

When my army finally returned to the de jure Kingdom of England to take revenge, I was faced with 10 to 1 odds and no allies strong enough to make a difference.  So I decided I would have the Nordic wife-stealer killed in his sleep. My (now technically) ex-wife was MORE than happy to contribute to the plot and he was killed in a carriage while travelling. My involvement was discovered and the Nordic King's son was ♥♥♥♥♥♥, and I could not diplomatically persuade him to free her.

So I tried a DIFFERENT plot against the son, except now I couldn't get anyone to back the plot. Even my ex-wife had moral qualms - she was free of her concubinage and had nothing personal against the 12 kid who we had thrust onto the throne. But I wanted my son and wife back.

I couldn't use brute force, I lacked the numbers.
I couldn't use diplomacy, I had ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off the Nords too much.
I couldn't use Intrigue, no one shared my vision.
I couldn't use Religion, I wasn't pious enough.

Sure enough, the 12-year old Nordic kid grew up to be a more terrifing fighter than his dad and decided to take his revenge by once again sieging Dorset.

I was eventually thrust right back into the familiar postion of Elodie - except instead of a dead lumen mother, I had a dead duke dad. A young girl with no allies or experience needed to fight her enemies.

Except where Elodie had magic powers and a kingdom's resouces, I was a poor muggle countess. It didn't end well.

So I started a NEW game where I took particular note of the original Nordic King I was fighting and what he did and I have managed not to draw any attention to myself thus far.

I am LOVING this game, but it was incredibly expensive even during the Summer Sale where everything was 75% off or more. That is perhaps the main problem with this game, although it has not deterred me.

reviewText:
If you are looking for a grand strategy game, this is it. I came to this game as a fan of the Total War series, and initially looked upon Crusader Kings II with trepidation. However, I can honestly say that this game more fully scratches the grand strategy itch than any other.

A word of warning, however. The learning curve is extremely steep. If you try to jump right in, you will surely drown! That being said, if you can devote the time to learn this game's expansive intracacies (every time I play, I learn more), you will not be disappointed.

Who I would recommend this game to: Any strategy gamer that is not satisfied with calling Clash of Clans" or "DoTa" a strategy game. If you wish the Civilization series had more depth
date: or the Total War series more historicity
recommended:
this game is hands down for you.

Who I would NOT recomment this game to: people with low attention spans.

For me
hoursPlayed: hands down the best strategy game I've played in years."

reviewText: Crusader kings II is the holy grail of grand strategy games. On the grand scale you control a king and his realm (Or a duke or count if you'd like) and make various decisions to benefit it. On the smaller scale of things, you become entwined in a web of international politics and plots, domestic politics and plots, feudal succession laws and many other things. It's a game where everything in the world actively affects everything else in the world. DLC is not required at all, but it does double up the game size with each DLC, each adding even more replay value to a great game.

reviewText:
A grand-strategy from the masters of the genre Paradox Development Studio. The game will feel familiar to those that have played other games from the developer, Europa Universalis etc, yet will be refreshing and worthwhile because of its focus on intrigue and dynasties rather than trade and nation level politics.

Crusader Kings II is one of the best, if not the best, grand-strategy game of recent years. The game offers hundreds of hours of gameplay (especially if you have the expansions) because of the vastly different experiences the various religions, cultures and ranks of nobility offer. The RPG elements and focus on your personal dynasty add another layer of depth with the micromanagement of every marriage, alliance and well placed dagger in the unfortunate cousin's back. The game is full of events from restoring the Roman Empire to building a flying machine, which add a lot of flavour and keep the playthroughs interesting and amusing.

The game also has a very good modding community, with mods ranging from the small ones that bring alternate flags and portraits to the total conversion mods such as:

'A song of Ice and Fire' mod:  Game of Thrones [forum.paradoxplaza.com]
'Elder Scrolls' mod:  Elder Kings [forum.paradoxplaza.com]

The mods, especially the total conversions, add a lot of value to the game.

The game is not beginner friendly, not by a long shot. Despite being more simple than other games in the genre the information overload will be a lot, especially for new players. If you're willing to take the time to learn the game, it will be an amazing experience.  I recommend the game to anyone who's interested Game of Thrones-esque intrigue.

reviewText: One of the most enjoyable games I've ever played. The amount of depth is amazing, and the text based build allows for very easy modding. Although some parts of the game may be ahistorical, owing the limitations of the game engine (Namely, the portrayal of Byzantium and the Islamic caliphates as decentralised, essentially feudal realms), there's still much fun to be had. With two years of DLC and patches under it's belt, and a further year (At least) to go, I can only see it getting better.

reviewText:
Played as a Germanic Frisia and raided the shorelines of England. After the king the great died and left the kingdom to his 14 year old son I decided to take the seduction focus and I made the Christian mother to the king a lover. I then decided to burn England again, sacrifice the mother to the Allfather and leave the kingdom filled with B A S T A R D S, my B A S T A R D S.

Crusader Kings 2 is by my opinion the best game from Paradox. If you really love to play games that makes you think or you love conquering land then there is no better choice than this.

What makes this game so good?: The fact that you take your own choices that will effect the future so much. You can start as the Holy Romans and form Prussia, or you can lose all and have to play as a small kingdom far east. The basic game is simulated to act the historical events, but you can change them and make your own history.
This strategic simulator will conquer more of your time than it will of Europe.

There are problems of course, handling your vassals, defending your kingdom and keeping your dynasty alive. But the worst thing is that you have to buy expansion moduels to play as other charakters or different religions. So buy the expansions, but only when it is sale on them.
If you are still holding back from buying it, then ask yourself. Do I love independence, difficulties and history?

reviewText:
Rating 8.5/10

Make sure you buy the CK2 Complete Pack on sale(GREAT VALUE FOR MONEY)

This is a must have for any grand strategy fan.  (BEWARE STEEP LEARNING CURVE)<by this i mean a good 6 hours or so to get the basics. Even after this you are always learning something. would recommend Arumba's CK2 Tutorial Series on youtube. Also great to watch to get an idea of the features in the game and the level of depth involved.

Features
.Manage your dynasty
.Plot to kill other characters in the game
. Amusing events and decision based on your characters traits and ambitions(Of which you can manage once you learn the game)
.Conquer lands for your county/duchy/kingdom/empire
.Manage your council and court
.And many many more

If you are still reading now for my review

I enjoyed 90% of this game, although there are thing's that paradox could have done better such as the warfare,Building management, religion and the whole pope minigame, But this is still a great title and i was very happy with my purchase. I spent hours on hours managing my dynasty,Court and my council. While this was happening i was also plotting against my enemies and even my own subjects in my kingdom/empire who were a troublesome sight to my reign. Also had to help my allies and keep an eye on my dynasty members(sisters/daughters) in particular, who i married off to people in larger empires outside my lands who i had high plans for. Overall this game is outstanding if you enjoy a nice in depth/complex empire and dynsaty management system.

reviewText: It has a VERY steep learning curve, but for strategy fans, I can't recommend it enough, its a very unique game. Basically, the goal is to last as long as you can, its over when ether you lose your last piece of land, or if your ruler dies without a heir. Its very complex, but so worth it once you get the hang of it. I mean really, how many games come along where you can say you had the Pope assassinated? Unlike a lot of strategy games, its not so much about build this and conqure everyone, its more about surviving and the political intrigue of the times. People will try to fabricate claims on your land, your second wife may try to have a son you had with your first wife assassinated so that her child will become the rightfull heir. You can start in Ireland and work your way up from count, to king, then conqure Scotland and England to form the Empire of Britannia. You can stratigically marry off your daughters to prestigous people of other countrys, then their sons will have claim to those lands. Theres different rules too, which you can change so that daughters can inherit, or that women can even inheret on the same grounds men do. There is a LOT to the game. The DLCs add even more, such as being able to play as pagens and sacrificeing your prisioners, if thats more your thing.

reviewText: I really like CKII. It is a rich, complex, and brilliant game, and I have loved every minute so far, although I have mainly played as pagan rulers. To fully enjoy it, I reccomend that you look around the map from time to time, and see what happens. One of the most interesting things I have seen happened in my Sudreijar save, in which Axum, a small african kingdom, captured Mecca and Medina, which led to various wars, culminating in an independent muslim king reigning in Mecca. During that same game, I challenged my heir, which was my cousin, to a Holmngang, in which he killed me. The kingdom was then divided between him and my sons, and I set about uniting it again in a series of bloody wars. CKII is unlike any other game I have ever played, and everyone should try it. It may seem overly complex and intimidating at first, but it is easy to get the hang of after a while, although I´m still pretty bad at it :p

reviewText:
Played this game alone and I married my cousin. I played multiplayer with my cousin and then married my cousin.
10/10 Best cousin marriage simulator. Good for the whole realm.




But for real, this game is absolutely incredible. I remember when I first saw this game. It was about three years ago and I totally thought this game looked like an overly complicated piece of junk. And boy, was I half right.
After totally brushing off this game I started getting really into Civ V. I really loved how immersive the game was and how it wonderfully wove together culture, technology, and history. Eventually, after 200 hours of gameplay, I grew tired of that game and moved on. I moved on to Warband and played over 200 hours of that wonderful game. Yet I still grew tired of it.

So I looked online for more strategy games and I came across this game again. At this point I was desperate for a strategy game that could also immerse me in a beautiful world while also giving me something I would take pride in fighting for. So I gave this game a chance and after 500 hours I am still playing this game. Crusader Kings 2 is an amazing grand strategy game that puts you not only in charge of a realm, but in charge of your family's house.  The goal of the game, if there is one to be found, is to bring as much glory to your realm and family name as you can. This can be attained by many different means and that is one of the things that makes this game great. You are put into a position of power in the Middle Ages and destiny is yours to write. However, this game can throw terrible twists your way. Your great genius leader can be killed in battle leaving your young daughter to take the throne in a world that hates female rulers. Or maybe you will find yourself hoping your King-Jeoffery-of-a-son dies so that way your strong, attractive, and genius son can take the throne. Or my greatest nightmare: You can be playing as an Eastern European nation and the Mongolian Hordes begin to knock on your door.

Crusader Kings is one of the greatest games I have every played. It is wildly complex and can take over 50 hours to master. But don't let that stop you from giving this game a try. Because once you get a feel for how the Crusader Kings 2 world works, you can let your ambitions run free and carve out a glorious realm with characters that somehow manage to create a story that seems like it could have happened.

10/10 would have my vassals revolt against my 16 year old female ruler during a Mongolian invasion for Poland so I can inherit France and the HRE again.

reviewText: While it's not for everyone, the hours I've sunk into this game are a testament to its quality. While not very graphically impressive, the game makes up for this lack by having highly detailed people and places, and is about as historically accurate as one can get.\n\nIt's really more of a Dynastic/Kingdom sandbox simulator than a game, and really lets you experience what it would have been like to be Emperor, King, Duke, or Count. Critical thinking, and long term strategy are essential to surviving (even your own children you groom to be your heir may try and murder you if you don't pay attention, or have an inept spymaster.) You're more or less just living a story as you decide to tell it. Playing it like any other game will result in frustration, and the extinction of your house within the first 100 years.

reviewText: Probably the best game Paradox has ever made. The game is a complex sandbox where you play as nobility in the real world, trying to forge your dynasty into every corner of Europe, Arabia or India. You can play anyone from a lowly count, up to the emperor of the medieval roman empires.\n\nIt has happened that I've devilishly laughed with great geniune delight as I expanded my kingdom of Burgundy deep into the HRE, wondering for just a moment why I don't have any friends. date: and that I now had to deal with an astronomically awkward inheiritance.\n\nThere are also many ways to challenge yourself though the game as you can choose to play either as a christian

reviewText:
Played this game alone and I married my cousin. I played multiplayer with my cousin and then married my cousin.
10/10 Best cousin marriage simulator. Good for the whole realm.




But for real, this game is absolutely incredible. I remember when I first saw this game. It was about three years ago and I totally thought this game looked like an overly complicated piece of junk. And boy, was I half right.
After totally brushing off this game I started getting really into Civ V. I really loved how immersive the game was and how it wonderfully wove together culture, technology, and history. Eventually, after 200 hours of gameplay, I grew tired of that game and moved on. I moved on to Warband and played over 200 hours of that wonderful game. Yet I still grew tired of it.

So I looked online for more strategy games and I came across this game again. At this point I was desperate for a strategy game that could also immerse me in a beautiful world while also giving me something I would take pride in fighting for. So I gave this game a chance and after 500 hours I am still playing this game. Crusader Kings 2 is an amazing grand strategy game that puts you not only in charge of a realm, but in charge of your family's house.  The goal of the game, if there is one to be found, is to bring as much glory to your realm and family name as you can. This can be attained by many different means and that is one of the things that makes this game great. You are put into a position of power in the Middle Ages and destiny is yours to write. However, this game can throw terrible twists your way. Your great genius leader can be killed in battle leaving your young daughter to take the throne in a world that hates female rulers. Or maybe you will find yourself hoping your King-Jeoffery-of-a-son dies so that way your strong, attractive, and genius son can take the throne. Or my greatest nightmare: You can be playing as an Eastern European nation and the Mongolian Hordes begin to knock on your door.

Crusader Kings is one of the greatest games I have every played. It is wildly complex and can take over 50 hours to master. But don't let that stop you from giving this game a try. Because once you get a feel for how the Crusader Kings 2 world works, you can let your ambitions run free and carve out a glorious realm with characters that somehow manage to create a story that seems like it could have happened.

10/10 would have my vassals revolt against my 16 year old female ruler during a Mongolian invasion for Poland so I can inherit France and the HRE again.

Played as a Germanic Frisia and raided the shorelines of England. After the king the great died and left the kingdom to his 14 year old son I decided to take the seduction focus and I made the Christian mother to the king a lover. I then decided to burn England again, sacrifice the mother to the Allfather and leave the kingdom filled with B A S T A R D S, my B A S T A R D S.

Crusader Kings 2 is by my opinion the best game from Paradox. If you really love to play games that makes you think or you love conquering land then there is no better choice than this.

What makes this game so good?: The fact that you take your own choices that will effect the future so much. You can start as the Holy Romans and form Prussia, or you can lose all and have to play as a small kingdom far east. The basic game is simulated to act the historical events, but you can change them and make your own history.
This strategic simulator will conquer more of your time than it will of Europe.

There are problems of course, handling your vassals, defending your kingdom and keeping your dynasty alive. But the worst thing is that you have to buy expansion moduels to play as other charakters or different religions. So buy the expansions, but only when it is sale on them.
If you are still holding back from buying it, then ask yourself. Do I love independence, difficulties and history?

reviewText: I remember when I had a family, friends, and a youthful figure. This game took all of that away, and gave me something better. Every day after school I sprint home to resume my Crusader Kings 2 journey, forging my dynasty to make it the greatest in all of Europe. My teachers tell me I will have to repeat the 8th grade, that my grades are slipping, I tell them to meet on the hills of Normandy where my dynasty reigns with an iron fist. My family has tried everything, whether it be cutting my computer cords, stealing my monitor, or turning off the power in our house; I always find a way to return to my beloved Crusader Kings 2. The first 200 hours of this game are a warmup lap, after you complete the warmup lap you realize you need at least another 600 hours to get the complete experience... After 800 hours, you cannot stop, and you realize this game has consumed your life in every aspect, but do you care? Of course not, because deep down you know that your real life doesnt matter anymore, only the lives of your characters in-game matter. Once you come to this realization, you will be at peace. I must finish this review now, my Chancellor has notified me that my liege lord is waging war, I must gather my troops and prepare for impending conflict. Farewell all, and pray for me.

reviewText: I really like CKII. It is a rich, complex, and brilliant game, and I have loved every minute so far, although I have mainly played as pagan rulers. To fully enjoy it, I reccomend that you look around the map from time to time, and see what happens. One of the most interesting things I have seen happened in my Sudreijar save, in which Axum, a small african kingdom, captured Mecca and Medina, which led to various wars, culminating in an independent muslim king reigning in Mecca. During that same game, I challenged my heir, which was my cousin, to a Holmngang, in which he killed me. The kingdom was then divided between him and my sons, and I set about uniting it again in a series of bloody wars. CKII is unlike any other game I have ever played, and everyone should try it. It may seem overly complex and intimidating at first, but it is easy to get the hang of after a while, although I´m still pretty bad at it :p

This is perhaps one of the best strategy games in modern age. While the in-game tutorial is somewhat lacking at best, that should NOT keep you from purchasing this incredible game. TL;DR

Don't come into this game expecting to dominate the feudal politics with open warfare alone. This game takes time, once you get to grips with the basics, this game is insanely addictive.

reviewText:
Crusader Kings 2 is real time/paused strategy game developed by Paradox Interactive. Same developer who made other great games like Europa Universalis 4, Victoria 2, Hearts of Iron 3 and Stellaris. This game is based on Middle Ages to start of renaissance, where EU4 starts. Without DLC starts around 1066, but if you have dlc's like Old Gods and Charlemagne you can start it on 700's.

However before saying this game is all about invading other lands like Civ and Total War, no. Because this game is unique. You rule your dynasty and lead it through the age. You have to control your family by marrying other people for example Holy Roman Empire's princesses. Then you extend your family and realm. Same time there is world map, where you can invade land, like in every strategy game. But only land available is Europe, North Africa and part of Asia.

There are many events in this game. I'll explain hordes, rebellions and crusades in this review. There are many hordes. For example Mongols and Abbasids. If you have Sunset Invasion DLC, Aztecs are gonna invade Europe too. Hordes born quickly and rise by invading all neighbor realms. They are hard to defeat but they collapse easily with rebellions. Rebellions are events where claimer of duchy of puppet state declare war on country and try to switch government or get independece. That's why you see all rebellions threats on your intrique menu, so you can prepare at threats or plot to kill threats. And last, crusades. If you part of catholic or orthodox religion, pope or archbishop might declare crusade to invade Jerusalem, Anatolia or any lands where real life crusaders were. You don't have to join crusade but if you join and get most points you'll gain all lands that were invaded in crusade.

Family relations are pretty important as your sons that have bad relation with you might try to kill you or start rebellion. And affairs are just gonna anger your wife and your children. However having family member in countries like Holy Roman Empire might help you make alliance with them, so that is useful. On my game, I just spammed my every daughter on big countries, HRE, England, France and Byzantium.

Combat works really well, but units are pretty hard to make and army levies might rise too big.

Overall this game is great and I had alot more fun with it than with Civ or EU4. I recommend it!
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pros: the game is truly phenomenal.
Cons: the DLCs are great but extremely expensive, better grab them when discounted.

Strategy lovers and history lovers are reunited with CK2, a gem of a game that lets you revive and/or alter several centuries of events just the way you want (sort of, because you'll have to work it through if your aim is to be crowned emperor). 55 DLCs and hundreds (thousands ?) of mods just make this game even better.

For example, the Game of Trones mod (based on the books), a total conversion, is simply one of the greatest things there is, because of its accuracy and the feelings it gives.

1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended
4) Highly recommended
5) This is a must play

reviewText:
Crusader Kings 2 is a very unique game. To date, I haven't played another strategy game like it, and it's likely there aren't any. This game can make somewhat similar games, like Civilization, feel quite disappointing.

This game is all about your family, politics, your characters, your religion, your culture... there's a lot of depth. And after you've played for a few hours, you should have a story worth telling to someone. Stories that alter history. It easily beats out almost every other strategy game I've played in this way.

This is one of the few games where it's okay to kill your wife, your brothers, and your uncle's 2-year-old child, all for the sole purpose of aspiring to be even greater than they were.

Be warned, this game can be very frustrating: You learn more through your failure than your success, and sometimes there's something big you've overlooked for the last day (or month) you've been playing. I highly recommend you try the demo and watch some people play this game online (Youtube, for example) before you're determined to buy it.

It also has some of the best modifications out there for any strategy game, including a Game of Thrones mod that's well acclaimed and probably the best Game of Thrones game out there.

As a sandboxy medieval European story simulator, this game shines. You will giggle at the death of little boys and marrying their sisters as you inherit land and claims for war. Very rarely do I feel like I waste my time with this game. There's no grinding. And Paradox tries to improve it with patch after patch, which is nice.

The only downside, in my opinion, is the way the DLC is released, with song packs, skin packs, etc. however, the higher priced DLC is worth buying for the most part - just read what it's about before you buy it and you should be good to go.

This is, by far, the best game Paradox has to offer, and one of the most worthy games on Steam to buy.

reviewText: Ever loved games like medieval total war but couldn't bother to do the RTS parts of the game? then this is just for you.\nCrusader kings 2 puts you in the role of your leader king,baron,patriarch whatever you decide to start with, unlike similar games you can't choose what you want to construct or what kind of units you want to train , but you can choose who will educate your sons, who do you want to marry , who do you want to war on via diplomacy tricks in order to expand your empire and much more including setting a plot to kill your  brother so you can become the next king and have it all ruined because of one the people who joined your conspiracy got drunk and didn't keep his mouth shut , no two runs are ever the same aside historical events.\nThe only downside i can see in this game is how most of the factions are dlc content ,if you want to experience being the leader of the turks and declare a jihad on half the christian empire then you need a dlc otherwise you can't play them same with a lot of really fun factions like venezian merchants.

reviewText:
If you have the patience or a friend to teach you how this game works, it´s a game you can easily spend hundreds of hours in. If you are into strategy games I can definately recommend this one. It´s not the easiest to learn, in fact, after fifty games you will still learn more about this game, and with the continuous supply of DLC you will not get bored of this game quickly.


Now, why is this game so great?

+ A big map that gets expanded occasionally. You can start of as a viking king in Norway and eventually rule India, or start as a Russian Slavic pagan and become emperor of Europe. And who knows what Paradox is preparing to add next?

+ A hundred of options with a thousand of choices. Whether you start off as a viking or a muslim, you will encounter similar problems. However, every religion, culture and country has it's own way of solving those. And as your character develops he will unlock (or block) other options. You'll never stop exploring these options.

+ Easier and harder gameplay is possible, so whether you are new or experienced you will always find your challenge

+ Great multiplayer, especially with friends. Whether you like PvPing or play versus the computer, a good multiplayer match will always keep you interested. Connecting to other players has been made easier (compared to how it was in the past), and is easily done via steam.

+ Events and results are random. You'll never know what happens, for you could be killed by bandits during your hajj to Mecca, or you could suddenly get an extra 100 gold.This can be very frustrating, or very interesting.

+ You can create your starting king with the ruler creater DLC

+ Loads of DLC that add new and interesting things to the game. When playing multiplayer, only the DLCs owned (and activated) by the host are available. If you play with friends, have the person who hosts most often get some DLCs, so the others won't need them.

+ Starting date can vary from 769 to 1337 (there currently are six bookmarks, respectively the Early Middle Ages (769), the Viking Age (867), the High Middle Ages (1066) , the Alexiad (1081) the Age of the Mongols (1241) and the Late Middle Ages (1337).

+ No game will every be the same. After a hundred years into the game, you will notice considerable differences in each game.


A game would not be realistic if not without flaws, so here are some of the downsides

- Event and results are random. You'll never know what happens, for you could be killed by bandits during your hajj to Mecca, or you could suddenly get an extra 100 gold. This can be very frustrating, or very interesting.

- Multiplayer can sometimes be unstable, especially if you play with more than 5 people. Desyncs will happen every now and then (usually you can play for an hour or two), and you have to restart your game to properly solve it. This is less common if you play with less player and if the internet connections are good. (If you have good internet, and so do your friends, this is MUCH less likely to happen.)

- At first, this game might be very complicated and confusing. I recommend playing with someone with experience, if possible.

- Once you get to a certain size, you will become quite unstoppable (although there are a few big armies coming to Europe, like the mongols, that might make you lose lands again).



Overall I would easily recommend this game. Once you grasp how this game works, you will be able to spend hours and hours of your time into this, exploring the near unlimited amount of options, and seeing how every game is available. If you play with friends, get a co-op game going.

9/10

reviewText:
Great, unique game that any grand strategy enthusiast should purchase.

Crusader Kings II fills an excellent niche of strategy where the goal is to control and survive internal struggles as it is to survive the machinations of your neighbors.  A full-blown character development and dynasty system gives incredible richness to the world and the player's attachment to character, family, and kingdom.

This is fantastic game for single or co-op play.  It takes a long time to learn and master, but once you've got it the game becomes very fun and satisfying.

My primary complaints lie in the underdeveloped economic side, underdeveloped religious system (especially for non-Catholics and non-Norse) slow casus-belli capture-one-county-at-a-time conquering system, and multiplayer instability.


Note: The developers have consistently released new content for the game, which is incredible.  A lot of the key additions are also given for free for vanilla users.  That said, there are some DLC expansions that add important new systems or create additional depth to existing ones, which therefore should be purchased with vanilla.  If on a tight budget, I would definitely pick up Old Gods.  All other DLC at your discretion.

reviewText: Started as the Umayyad Caliphate in 860. Changed my ruler with ruler designer to a Shia. Conquered Asturias, conquered Aquitaine, took West Francia and everything was going great. And then the Pope got involved. Crusade for Aquitaine with all of Europe against me and like a badass, decide to send all 15k of my men to Rome. Take Rome before they have a chance to react and capture the pope. Win the Crusades and get 2000 prestige. Marry my daughter to the Abbasid Caliph. Ruler dies of old age at 67. Heir's s a brave strategist. Establish empire of Hispania. Start conquering Britannia by the bunches. Have to stop when I have 2 peasant revolts and an independence revolt in my homeland and crush them. Realize my guy has a weak claim on the Abbasid Caliphate. Check out the ruler. Turns out he is a Greek! And as a good Muslim ruler, I decide to liberate the empire from him. Luckily for me, They  had a Shia rising event. Conquer them and both of the Caliphs of Islam are my vassals and then bam, a crusade plus decadence revolt, and the odd liberation force my empire from the largest in the world to nothing but a kingdom. 10/10 only this happens in CK2

reviewText: This game is the largest stakeholder simulator ever created. Make sure to keep your vassals and court happy to avoid revolutions or any sort of a turmoil. I have enjoyed the game so far. In particular, I liked the random events that take place throughout the game. For example, your son’s wife can get possessed by a demon and slay half of your family or your younger son will decide to assassinate you and all his older brothers to inherit the crown. Equally, sometimes you are that very person who coldly murders most of your family while being driven by hunger for power. In any scenario, you will have plenty of fun while rewriting world’s history. It feels like a game with a storylines alike Game of Thrones – intrigues, assassinations, betrayals, seduction and other joys of life.\n\nI would personally advise to play this game on Ironman mode only, as it forces you to embrace all the chaos you have caused and all challenges that have emerged in the game, forging your mind to be more strategic next time and also not trust anyone.

reviewText:
This is a premiere strategy game.

It is NOT tactical.

Let me repeat that.

Tactics are NOT NOT NOT involved.

I see too many people try this game expecting something akin to Total War only to get turned off by the lack of tactical decisions. Strategy" games are more akin to simulation games in essence. You plan your course of action through dangerous circumstances to achieve the best victory possible. Strategy is knowing when to fight
recommended: how to take advantage of your situation for long-term benefits
hoursPlayed: and other similar questions. Tactics is "how to fight" and this game does not cover that. It is a question of logistics rather than tactics. Do you have enough troops
voteText: rather than are your troops fighting at optimal efficieny. Do you have the defensive high ground
helpfulPercent: rather than whether or not this unit happens to be in good terrain at any given time. Do you catch the enemy army off guard
votesHelpful: rather than using flanking to decimate part of the army.\n\nIf you expect a Civilization-esque game
votesTotal: or something like Total War. Check your expectations. Go online
votesFunny: and watch gameplay before buying. You are probably in for a surprise."

reviewText: Ever loved games like medieval total war but couldn't bother to do the RTS parts of the game? then this is just for you.\nCrusader kings 2 puts you in the role of your leader king,baron,patriarch whatever you decide to start with, unlike similar games you can't choose what you want to construct or what kind of units you want to train , but you can choose who will educate your sons, who do you want to marry , who do you want to war on via diplomacy tricks in order to expand your empire and much more including setting a plot to kill your  brother so you can become the next king and have it all ruined because of one the people who joined your conspiracy got drunk and didn't keep his mouth shut , no two runs are ever the same aside historical events.\nThe only downside i can see in this game is how most of the factions are dlc content ,if you want to experience being the leader of the turks and declare a jihad on half the christian empire then you need a dlc otherwise you can't play them same with a lot of really fun factions like venezian merchants.
