reviewText:
Here's a single session description which will hopefully strike the reader with the joy I experienced. To be honest, it's more like a review for myself than an actual help information but forgive me for being egoistic this time. Not the last time though.

That day I was the ruler of some small territory in Ireland. My name was long so I preferred to call myself Ua which is actually a part of it. I was 47 years old with a wife and a few kids. They all were very talented siblings with good education except for the last one named Dub-da. I decided to experiment a little with him so he ended up not having a guardian and betrothed to a dumb woman. People of my tribe knew me as 'the sloth with good strategic skills. My treasury was almost empty but I decided to invest last coins in some risky business opportunity. Some oversea lord invited us to his country for a business discussion!

It was a question of whether or not we should buy some merchant's ship or hire bandits to capture one. We hired bandits and were readly to sail off. Some priests catched up and asked to join us. 'Sure sure come in feel yourself like in the Heavens'. After a few days of sailing priests declared that they haven't seen the crew which was fully consist of thieves and bandits.

We finally arrived at the castle of our potential business partner. Feeling ourselves a little uncomfortable we realized that we forgot something important - a gift. Thankfully
date: on our ship we had: a dozen of good breeded horses
recommended: some rich cloth and a pouch of herbs. So with a smile on his face
hoursPlayed: Ua presented the pouch as a gift and it was the moment which started a long friendship.\n\nThe oversea lord invited us for a dinner. My brother was a barbarian just like me as you probably figured out already so he was very hungry and ate the food with his bare hands. The lord noticed that and asked me to do something about it because YES it was an issue. I replied 'What?! I'm hungry too!' and with a cavemen cruelty I attacked a nearby roasted rabbit
voteText:
punching it before eating. It was already dark outside when the atmosphere in the throne room suddenly changed. Excusing  everyone I ran off the room then up the stairs disrobing as I go and finally standing completely naked on a balcony in front of the full moon howling 'aaaAAAAAOOOOOOooooo'. The guards found me soon.

Next day some of my priests started a discussion with the Lord about something important but I just witnessed it from the ground next to them. It was our last day there.

After sailing off to our lands I had a signed trading contract between our nations for two years!! #OOhYEAH! #contracthype

After coming back some events took place such as:

I woke up and noticed that my garden looked wild with tall weeds and fibres everywhere on the walls and statues so you can't pass without a good sharp sword. So i decided to clean it up and to do it myself! That was the moment when people stopped to call me a sloth but instead started to call me a gardener! Who would think that at the age of 48 I'll become a gardener?

One year after I recieved a book of poetry. I digged through it twice or so and discovered a great sympathy to this craft. So here and there I started to white poems and verses. I didn't consider myself a poet and thought that all this was just a fun hobby. BUT WHY anywhere I go I hear people singing and reading MY POETRY??!! Who would believe that at the age of 49 I'll become a poet?

Somebody sent me a bird. It was an eagle-kind and I took it with me for a hunt! The bird was brilliant! We came back to the big house with lots and lots of rabbit corpses! Who would imagine that at the age of 50 I'll become a falconer?

After these events my friend

reviewText:
If you have the patience or a friend to teach you how this game works, it´s a game you can easily spend hundreds of hours in. If you are into strategy games I can definately recommend this one. It´s not the easiest to learn, in fact, after fifty games you will still learn more about this game, and with the continuous supply of DLC you will not get bored of this game quickly.


Now, why is this game so great?

+ A big map that gets expanded occasionally. You can start of as a viking king in Norway and eventually rule India, or start as a Russian Slavic pagan and become emperor of Europe. And who knows what Paradox is preparing to add next?

+ A hundred of options with a thousand of choices. Whether you start off as a viking or a muslim, you will encounter similar problems. However, every religion, culture and country has it's own way of solving those. And as your character develops he will unlock (or block) other options. You'll never stop exploring these options.

+ Easier and harder gameplay is possible, so whether you are new or experienced you will always find your challenge

+ Great multiplayer, especially with friends. Whether you like PvPing or play versus the computer, a good multiplayer match will always keep you interested. Connecting to other players has been made easier (compared to how it was in the past), and is easily done via steam.

+ Events and results are random. You'll never know what happens, for you could be killed by bandits during your hajj to Mecca, or you could suddenly get an extra 100 gold.This can be very frustrating, or very interesting.

+ You can create your starting king with the ruler creater DLC

+ Loads of DLC that add new and interesting things to the game. When playing multiplayer, only the DLCs owned (and activated) by the host are available. If you play with friends, have the person who hosts most often get some DLCs, so the others won't need them.

+ Starting date can vary from 769 to 1337 (there currently are six bookmarks, respectively the Early Middle Ages (769), the Viking Age (867), the High Middle Ages (1066) , the Alexiad (1081) the Age of the Mongols (1241) and the Late Middle Ages (1337).

+ No game will every be the same. After a hundred years into the game, you will notice considerable differences in each game.


A game would not be realistic if not without flaws, so here are some of the downsides

- Event and results are random. You'll never know what happens, for you could be killed by bandits during your hajj to Mecca, or you could suddenly get an extra 100 gold. This can be very frustrating, or very interesting.

- Multiplayer can sometimes be unstable, especially if you play with more than 5 people. Desyncs will happen every now and then (usually you can play for an hour or two), and you have to restart your game to properly solve it. This is less common if you play with less player and if the internet connections are good. (If you have good internet, and so do your friends, this is MUCH less likely to happen.)

- At first, this game might be very complicated and confusing. I recommend playing with someone with experience, if possible.

- Once you get to a certain size, you will become quite unstoppable (although there are a few big armies coming to Europe, like the mongols, that might make you lose lands again).



Overall I would easily recommend this game. Once you grasp how this game works, you will be able to spend hours and hours of your time into this, exploring the near unlimited amount of options, and seeing how every game is available. If you play with friends, get a co-op game going.

9/10

reviewText:
Crusader Kings 2 is a very unique game. To date, I haven't played another strategy game like it, and it's likely there aren't any. This game can make somewhat similar games, like Civilization, feel quite disappointing.

This game is all about your family, politics, your characters, your religion, your culture... there's a lot of depth. And after you've played for a few hours, you should have a story worth telling to someone. Stories that alter history. It easily beats out almost every other strategy game I've played in this way.

This is one of the few games where it's okay to kill your wife, your brothers, and your uncle's 2-year-old child, all for the sole purpose of aspiring to be even greater than they were.

Be warned, this game can be very frustrating: You learn more through your failure than your success, and sometimes there's something big you've overlooked for the last day (or month) you've been playing. I highly recommend you try the demo and watch some people play this game online (Youtube, for example) before you're determined to buy it.

It also has some of the best modifications out there for any strategy game, including a Game of Thrones mod that's well acclaimed and probably the best Game of Thrones game out there.

As a sandboxy medieval European story simulator, this game shines. You will giggle at the death of little boys and marrying their sisters as you inherit land and claims for war. Very rarely do I feel like I waste my time with this game. There's no grinding. And Paradox tries to improve it with patch after patch, which is nice.

The only downside, in my opinion, is the way the DLC is released, with song packs, skin packs, etc. however, the higher priced DLC is worth buying for the most part - just read what it's about before you buy it and you should be good to go.

This is, by far, the best game Paradox has to offer, and one of the most worthy games on Steam to buy.

reviewText:
This is indeed grand strategy. And it is excellent.

Multiple aspects of this game elevate it to its status at the pinnacle of its genre. First of all, the deciding factor for me that makes it better than other Paradox games is the added RPG element. No longer are you simply commanding a country and desperately trying to stop inflation. Now you also feverishly work to impregnate your barren wife and secure an heir while assasinating your cousins left and right. If that doesn't sound like fun I don't know what does.

There's also the great open-ended freedom of this game. Unlike Civ, which is simply a race to dominate, Crusader Kings allows you to do whatever the heck you want. Feel like taking on the Golden Horde as King Kazimierz of Poland? Give it a shot. Or just chill as Earl Murchard in Ireland where literally nothing happens.

Did I mention that there's a 32 person multiplayer mode?

TL;DR- You should totally get this game.

reviewText:
This is indeed grand strategy. And it is excellent.

Multiple aspects of this game elevate it to its status at the pinnacle of its genre. First of all, the deciding factor for me that makes it better than other Paradox games is the added RPG element. No longer are you simply commanding a country and desperately trying to stop inflation. Now you also feverishly work to impregnate your barren wife and secure an heir while assasinating your cousins left and right. If that doesn't sound like fun I don't know what does.

There's also the great open-ended freedom of this game. Unlike Civ, which is simply a race to dominate, Crusader Kings allows you to do whatever the heck you want. Feel like taking on the Golden Horde as King Kazimierz of Poland? Give it a shot. Or just chill as Earl Murchard in Ireland where literally nothing happens.

Did I mention that there's a 32 person multiplayer mode?

TL;DR- You should totally get this game.

reviewText:
Crusader Kings 2 is a strategy game from Paradox Interactive.
It was released in 2012 and is still playable. why you might ask?
The game is a grand strategy game that lets you play as the head of any European, Minor Asian, North African or Indian dynasty, what happens when you die? Well, you continue playing as your heir!

The easiest way to think of this game is like a slightly more historical Civilization but with elements of The Sims (The family planning) because you are not only ruling your kingdom, you are spending time with your wife, marrying off your daughter, plannings feasts, etc.

There are endless of replayability in this game since everytime you play you and all other AI characters wont stumble upon the same problems, or victories. One game you might marry a cute blonde, have a genious child who later conquers half of Europe, but in the other you might not even get a kid cause you apparently are sterile and your incompetent brother inherits your kingdom, throwing it into a decade long civil war!

You'll have to look after your faith, your family, your kingdom and your destiny!
Will you end up in the glorious battles of the Crusade, or will you fall to instant death after your
wild son by mistake" pushed you from your balcony while inspecting your capital.

This is probably one of those games which I really never will stop playing

reviewText:
A solid example of a once great game ruined through pointless revisions and unnecessary changes to the core mechanics. After patch 2.5 the gameplay is more tedium and frustration than it is fun or interesting, and CKII has become so buggy that it's borderline unplayable as certain government types.

This game has been progressively worsening for a quite a while now, but conclave has absolutely broken the experience.

Why?

-The council exists only as a gameplay obstruction as opposed to an interesting feature on it's own.

-Managing anything larger than a small kingdom will now result in endless revolts to increase council power, with very little the player can do to avoid it.

-Defensive pacts are an interesting idea, but ultimately don't play nice with the game mechanics and aren't very historically accurate. (For an excellent example I played as Carloman Karling and I had the invasion of Saxony event fire, due to my previous war to press my claim on West Francia almost every independent slavic pagan declared war on me to defend the Saxons. Which by the way, makes absolutely no sense and results in an almost unwinnable conflict.)

-Shattered retreat suffers from a similar problem mechanically while being a good idea in theory, it simply doesn't work well in game and makes some conflicts ridiculously difficult or just pointless.(holy wars and prepared invasions are the best examples of this)

-The new education system makes creating a decent heir mostly reliant on rng as opposed to a chosen guardian's existing traits.

Despite all this I would still say this is a decent game, but I can't honestly recommend it anymore. If you're going to buy CKII, get it on sale and avoid some of the dlc. Also roll back to a patch prior to conclave for a better experience.

reviewText:
If you've ever played Civilization and thought it would be great if the whole game were the middle ages and I actually got to oppress the peasants, then you will enjoy this game. Similarly, if your family reunions make you wish you could speed up time and exert exacting control over who everyone in your family marries, this game will really blow your hair back. And finally, if you like playing The Sims but wish you could invade your neighbor and burn their ugly house down, well, I count myself fortunate to not be your vassal.

The gameplay really nails a humorous historical blend of strategy, simulation and role playing. The user interface is packed with information that can draw you in for hours, once you master the very steep learning cliff. The graphics are fairly minimal, but honestly just right for the game.

Unfortunately, so many of the extras that you wish you had control over are fairly pricey DLC, for what they get you. Want to tell your uppity heir to shave his stupid moustache? $4.99. Tired of everyone looking the same, wearing the same 5 outfits or having historically inaccurate ethnicities? $1.99, $0.99 and more for each part of the globe.

They have expanded the game several times, and the features continue to be added even if you don't by the expansion. From this standpoint, you can get many hours of new gaming experience out of it.

However this makes for an unpredictable experience. I bought the game to enjoy multiplayer with my wife. While the added features are great, the stability of the game has its ups and downs. Recently, the Mac version of the game has been very difficult to enjoy. Crashes to desktop and out-of-sync errors become more and more common as our conquests abound and demense expands. Any more, we can't reliably go for more than hour without one of us suffering a setback and having to fully reload the game.

Another common problem is that the game will protest that we have different versions when setting up the multiplayer server. This requires us to fully reload the game again.

I love the game and wish I could play it more. I'm not opposed to paid or free expansions and feature additions, but given the choice between a rock solid, unchanging game and a buggy, evolving game, I'll choose the former every time.

reviewText:
Really not my sort of game, despite me trying my darndest to enjoy it, for I have friends who love it. Thirty hours in and it still only makes limited sense to me (and no, I'm not a complete and utter idiot). Far too much seems dependent on luck, for a start. Event pop-ups occur where you can make some rather limited decisions, and there will be cases of 'fourty-percent chance something you don't want happens, sixty-percent something you do want happens'. Quite a lot of cases of that, in fact. If that makes for enjoyable gameplay for some people, then have at it - I'm not stopping you. For me on the other hand, constantly saving so that I can reload if I get buggered over by RNG isn't what I'd consider to be fun (or I guess you could play ironman mode and let fate take its toll, though I rather play the slots at a casino than this all day, for they offer about the same level of entertainment and cost the same, what with this game's ludicrous amounts of DLC).

Most of the game seems to consist of waiting. Wait for your piety and prestige stats, both of which are doing some very subtle things you probably won't realise at first due to the tutorial mode failing to teach you much of anything. You can speed things up, but then I suppose it's just a case of waiting for the things you want to happen but faster. Apparently there's strategy involved, but if you can make sense of it you're doing better than I did. Infantry units get combat bonuses when standing on certain terrain for example, but good luck telling what sort of terrain you're on as it's pretty damned hidden away - I only figured out how to tell about twenty-five hours in. If you do realise what's going on, good luck telling if that bonus is ACTUALLY having an effect and isn't bugged, like a lot of things in Crusader Kings 2 seemingly are.

Then there's the fact you have no actual goal to achieve presented to you. Some people love that, apparently, take Minecraft's success for example (though even Mojang decided to add an 'end boss' to their game). I personally just sit there and wonder why did I pay for something that's telling me to make my own fun?". If you have any hobbies

reviewText:
When I first discovered Crusader Kings 2 I immediately knew it was something I was sure to enjoy.  It takes place in a historic medieval setting, incorporates strategy, role playing and simulation elements, and puts you, the player, in the center of a huge world full of dynamic AI individuals and dynasties.  In spite of knowing CK2 contained all of these elements, I did admittedly have a hard time penetrating the game at first.  It took me a few hours of watching let’s plays to figure it out, but once I did so the numerous strategies and activities available became easy to access and execute.  Having said all of that, I’d like to move forward with this review by conveying why this game might appeal to someone not typically interested in grand strategy titles (of whom I count myself one).

My disinterest in grand strategy games stems from my preference for micro-level strategy, role playing, and simulation.  I enjoy games where you control a single person thriving to prevail in a larger community of likewise minded characters.  I’m not a fan of god games because I don’t want to have control over everything.  I prefer my character to be bound by the same rules as everyone else living in his or her world.  By the same token I don’t particularly enjoy empire building because it seems too detached from the individuals involved.  I like to know my character, understand their traits and motivations, and help shape who they are.  This is EXACTLY what CK2 offers.  In many ways it is a deeper role playing game than just about any I have played.  Characters can have genetic, personality, earned, and ascribed traits of numerous types.  Some of these you acquire through decision making and others by chance or through “breeding.”

Beyond the exceptional role playing and subsequent investment in one’s character(s) in CK2 are numerous other features that make it appealing.  As I’ve mentioned, you only really have direct control over your character but you have indirect control over your court (including your family) and your vassals.  This isn’t to suggest they’ll do whatever you say.  Remember, CK2 places you at the whim and mercy of rules and laws just like every other AI (or human) controlled player.  This is where the strategy comes in.  Should you change a law in your realm to give you more control over vassals even though it might upset some of them and lead to a rebellion?  Should you betroth your daughter to a powerful neighbor and form an alliance even though her children may inherit a claim on your titles?  These are some of the routine decisions you’ll have to make in CK2, and they constitute what I would probably label as “social strategy” – others might prefer to simply call this intrigue.

I could go on, but suffice to say CK2 is nearly the perfect game for someone like me who enjoys simulation, role playing and strategy in a dynamic living world where you are not the hero or a god – just another actor trying to get ahead.  You’ll go through cycles in your games.  I’ve been on top as a king only to fall to invaders and become the vassal of a hated enemy.  I’ve had an amazing ruler followed by a fool, having to struggle to keep my vassals happy.  Your characters won’t live forever, but their dynasty can earn a name for itself in history.  All of this happens on a grand scale but is viewed through a microcosmic lens of an individual that is part of a family.  Yes, it IS a medieval soap opera, and it’s amazing.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Review: Crusader Kings 2 Pc game

CKII is my favourite stategy game and i play it a lot.
Most of Paradox's games ar realy complex and hard to get into but CKII is
actually relatively easy to pick up. But if you're willing to bust your butt a little in the beginning to pick it up, it will reward you with a very enjoyable game experience in the end.

Presentation
While the game can overwhelm you at first, Paradox gives you very easy and manageble menu's and the interface is overall very well done.

Sound
Crusader Kings II doesn't feature much in the way of sound effects or voice acting, but it does feature a lot of very high-quality soundtrack which is relevant to the game.

Gameplay
The gameplay is the best part of the game with all the features like religion, war and diplomacy. Part of what makes it so interesting is that you control not a country or an empire, but a family dynasty that transcends national boundaries.



With all this in mind I give this game a 9 out of 10.

reviewText:
Crusader Kings 2 is a great original grand strategy game incompusing vast amounts of management and entrigue that most players will not be able to wrap their heads around their first attempt or even two playing without the help of a expieranced friend sitting behind them.

From top to bottom there are characters in every part of every kingdom and empire no matter how big or how small, how powerful or weak those characters exist and can make huge accomplishments if chance or will provide them with the means. Empire > King(s) > Dukes > Counts > Barons, Mayors, Bishops > Your councilers > a plethera of courtiers > and huge armys, what do you do with this giant mathmatical fractoral? Who knows what you want but each part of the chain has people that want individual things and they will try to guide the system to their will if you don't.

This is the game of thrones. You either live or you die. There is no middle ground." AND IT REALLY IS JUST LIKE GAME OF THRONES AND ITS AWESOME!"

reviewText:
This the my absolute favorite and easily most played game. I love the depth and the detail of making sure that my dynasty rises through the ranks from Count to Emperor over the course of many hundreds of years. I would also like to say that while this game's main disadvantages are limited they are present. Mainly the way war is run, it is accurate for the era which is cool however it does make it quite difficult. I also didn't like how slow many of the other nations were in becoming powerful and warmongering, as well as how stable many of them turned out to be.

The MODS for this game, namely Game of Thrones and Elder Kings breathed hundreds of hours of life into this game for me each offering my dreams of being the occupant of the Iron Throne or the High King of Skyrim.

My accolades for this game could go on and on, but hey just look at how many hours I have played... that says how wonderful this game truely can be!

reviewText:
Buying Crusader Kings 2!? The game by itself should be in the bucket list of every Strategy gameplayers.  Gameplay, strategy, actions, reality are great. BUT (yea it is a huge but) with lots of DLC without knowing which one I need for core which ones are secondary, it creates a huge consideration buble in my mind.

On the financial perspective you should not buy this game nor support the studio, because there is no need for extream number of DLC's like Train Simulator. We had a economic crisis. You have customers with limited budget because you actually develop this game for niche (Strategy Game) players. If the studio wants to make more money they should release less DLC more main game content. So from my point of view, game is must but with this marketing/sales strategy it deserves to be on hold list till they release Game Of the Year/Legendary" full content package with a 75% discount.

6/10 because of studious sales/development strategy."

reviewText:
This is rather a simulation than a game. It has synchronisation issues and crashes in multiplayer sometimes.  the player need an imense amount of time. The game does not really have a steam integration neither does it help players connect with other players. it has a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of DLCs at insane prices. there is almost no music and the extra tracks are DLCs that cost extra.
It has hell long loding screens. it has a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ tutorial which is probably the most boring thing to get into ever.

But i still would recommend it. its a very good game. its complex. fun to play with friends and has many other very cool features. its one of those games you can play almost passively at one time and very actively at another.

If you are looking for a world domination game this probably ain't really the thing, because it takes very long time to ammess smaller regions with war and war usually brings less new land than a few well placed marriages.

31 hours of playing and i'm still not sure if i really understand all the mechanics. so yes this game is great, but its surely not everyones taste.

reviewText: I love this game. Whenever I feel like playing a Game of Thrones game, this has so far been the closest thing to that experience for me. Don't mistake this for a replacement experience for a game like Europa Universalis or Total War, because while you certainly have the ability to run and expand your own country, this game is more about dealing with individual people and climbing your way up to a place of power (and then staying there!).

reviewText:
This game is the most accessible and least buggy game that Paradox has ever released.

You can unify your lands through marriage or mace, conquer Europe, go from Count of Dublin to King of Africa over the course of generations, or merely try to hold your kingdom together in the face of your relatives, who might not be so numerous or so quarrelsome if you didn't feel like having 10 kids a generation or two back.

Ultimately, Crusader Kings 2 is a game of emergent story. I don't remember my conquests as much as I remember the time that a once-favored cousin in Ulster managed to grab a piece of Italy through marriage and immediately defected to the Holy Roman Empire, leading to a massive war as I attempted to bring my wayward vassal to heel and left me managing a motley crew of dissatisfied Italians who now owed fealty to a distant Irish liege.

reviewText:
An incredibly steep learning curve but once you understand how things work it becomes fairly easy. Pick a country/empire/duchy and see how far you can lead your dynasty. Instead of playing as a country you play as a dynasty. You are represented by 1 member at a time. When that member dies you take over their heir. Through diplomacy, bribery, arranged marriages and assassinations you gain position in the world. Position yourself to inherit entire kingdoms.

There is no goals except the ones you make yourself. There are some goals laid out in the game but you don't have to follow them at all. If you want to take over Europe as the Byzantine Empire then go right ahead. My last playthrough as the Byzantine Empire I conquered Germany and was working on France. I stopped playing that because the expansion The Old Gods" was released and I decided I wanted to see what was different.

Overall a very satisfying game that doesn't hold your hand. It gives you this sandbox and says "Go wild!".


"
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: CK2 is a grand strategy game which deals in dynasties and people, not nations and governments, and it's all the more addictive as a result. You can play to win- maximise your stats, work the systems and never marry a hunchback. Or you can roleplay it- if your character is a cruel, craven drunkard with a penchant for impaling his enemies, don't shy away from executing your imprisoned brother or murdering the heir of France in a tragic hunting accident"!\n\nI have got more fun out of this than a dozen other games. I cannot recommend it enough."

reviewText: I bought this game and then for the next week barely managed to keep eating and sleeping. I was wary because Paradox's last title, while historically brilliant, had a bit too high a ratio of menus and info to meaningful decisions. This game on the other hand is not only a fantastic representation of the period but also perhaps the best alternative history engine ever created. If you like management games with omnipresent failure conditions (Tropico, for example) and you're okay with making up your own goals or playing for the sake of seeing what happens, then you have to get this.

reviewText: Over the years I've logged over 1250 hours in this game. To say that it is one of my favorites would be an obvious given. What i like the most about it is that it focuses on the lives of a dynasty that I can create and develop over the annals of medieval European history. With all of the expansions this can also be extended to the mid east and Indian subcontenant.  The game continues to evolve with each successive addition to add more and more variety between governing types, religions, cultures, and even lifestyles. I would not call it high action, though it has its moments, but a game that can be paced and simply enjoyed in terms of strategy. If you love strategy and the intrigue of dynasty building this game is for you.\n\nAs a bonus; if you're a fan of game of thrones.. the game of thrones mod is amazing.

reviewText:
One of the best games I have ever played. A must for all strategy fans.

Contains Beauitifully crafted, deep gameplay. It is almost RPG like in parts, with each character having their own distinct personality traits. It allows you to directly take controll of your ruling familys life and relationships, this playing a pivitol role in how the gameplay is shaped.

The game has great longevity, but even if you get fed up with the developers content there are many mods out there for you to enjoy.
